pros:
ADC is a great place to work if:
You value stability, consistency, and reliability. 
If you're paying for a house, raising a family, and want to work at a place that will provide steady work without any of the stress that comes from never knowing if your company will be paying you, or even there, tomorrow.
Your like it if your work touches millions, and helps folks with diabetes live better lives.
You want to work at a  place that takes very good care of it's people when it comes to things like benefits,  retirement options, and salaries. The goal is to recruit and retain, not recruit and dispose.
Management is driven by sustaining the company, not by being flashy or cutting edge.
cons:
All that being said, it's boring as hell. 
There are none of what the bay area skilled sector has come to think of of as "expected perks"... i.e. no gym, no fancy chefs on staff, no beer fridays, no parties, no weird architectural flourishes. This is an old-growth company run on traditional principles, and has no truck with that kind of silliness.
Office politics and company culture reflect that as well. It is, for want of a better word, a total cube farm. The movie "Office Space" may as well have been written about portions of this company. If you can handle that level of bland, then you'll be fine, if not, you'll go nuts.
If you spend too much time thinking about the fact that our growth model relies explicitly upon millions more people getting a horrible life threatening illness, it can get a little weird.

job_title: Front Line Leader in Sturgis, MI
pros:
Pay and benefits are great for the Sturgis, MI area.  This is also a great place to get experience since they have such a hard time getting and retaining staff; your self driven educational opportunities are pretty much endless.  

There is a lot of soft skills and concepts training available; from leadership development to excel classes to health and fitness and even stress/burnout management.  There is little support for the implementation of these skills, but most companies don’t even offer the training, so this is a big plus.

Being part of a larger global company with multiple divisions, there is incredible growth and travel opportunity if someone were inclined and in a position to commit themselves.
cons:
Hard skills training from experienced people is hard to come by here.  The group has succeeded by the skin of its teeth for many decades and prides itself on scrappiness, hard work, and long hours.  I repeat, long hours.

This has caused poor work/life balance, operational  inefficiencies, and burnout.  When people can leave or retire, they do so as quickly as they can.  This leads to poor retention rate of talent that is able to effectively train new generations as well as a purging of experience that can leverage their knowledge to implement long term solutions that would fix the aforementioned problems.

A great place to be able to afford a family, they need to give their employees the time to be able to raise one though.

job_title: Engineering Intern in Abbott Park, IL
pros: The internship program is well established, especially at Abbott Park. Not only are interns paired with a manager, who generally acts as a mentor for the summer, but there are several intern-only social events run by the program. These allow for the interns to form a sense of community within Abbott in among themselves. Other events include a meet and greet session with senior level management from all divisions, a day of seminars on professional growth and ethics, and a dinner at the Abbott House where CEO Miles White speaks (and often stays for dinner and chats with the interns) and each table of interns has a VP or senior manager at the table. Networking is huge and is encouraged through the program. It's a great place to gain experience.
cons: Expectations as far as working hours as not always explicitly stated and can be cause for either not enough time to finish projects or too much time sitting at the office for no reason. For permanent employees, there is little interaction with upper level management and the CEO, whereas the interns met him at least once over the summer. Abbott, like many employers, also tends to hire out of their current internship pool. Thus, if you intern with Abbott early in your college career but do not return to intern the following summers, the chances of you entering the Professional Development Program once you graduate tend to decrease.

pros: Most of the people in IT that you work with are passionate about what they do.  Compensation and benefits are above average.  The overall company genuinely believes in its products and the people they benefit.

pros: Abbott has a long history of providing quality pharmaceuticals and medical products.  I have always believed that I am selling the best product in my market, which makes it much easier to sell. Abbott provides some benefits that many companies don't, like a pension plan and profit sharing in addition to a 401K.  When my personal circumstances have required me to move Abbott has always found me a job in my new hometown.  Abbott also does a great job of keeping employees even when drugs go generic or sales forces get downsized.  I don't know anyone who's actually been laid off from Abbott, they always get placed in a new position.  So overall, great benefits, job security and a great products to sell.  That's why I've been with Abbott so long.
cons: Abbott's technology is sometimes outdated by the time it gets rolled out to the field.  Implementing new systems is slow, and some of the current systems were never any good (like OMEGA, the sample management portal).  Some things that seem like simple fixes are never going to get changed because someone's pride or their entire career is entwined with a certain software program or report.  Abbott is conservative with buying new data or new technology.

I used to love working for Abbott Nutrition, but this department has been moving in the wrong direction for a long time.

pros: Benefits are very good. People are very friendly. North burbs of Chicago are very low cost of living compared to nearby areas of other larger cities on either coast.
cons:
Politics - to set in the ways of doing everything the "Abbott" way, or the "way it's always been done." Abbott almost never has real turnover for those who have been with the company for 5+ years so the more tenured IC's or low-mid managers have no current/relevant skills to speak of. This makes integrating new technology or new business processes akin to moving a mountain even if it's for very simple tools.

Another major con is career advancement although for me it wasn't too bad. review_title: Abbott is a great place to work for someone who fits the culture.
pros: There is a big, corporate campus feel to working at Abbott.  There are a lot of benefits offered on site that are great for families in the area.  Being a large company, there are many places where you could land.  Miles White is an excellent CEO who can deliver on a strategic plan on a consistent basis.
cons: Abbott is a little slow to adapt to an ever-changing workplace.  I felt very behind the times using older software tools that have replacements that are much more efficient that have been on the market for years.  The culture is very hierarchical and feels very dated.   The different groups have their own demands of shared services but there is no clear 'Global' ownership on many things.  The Abbott Park campus is also very far from the city of Chicago, so you are limited in where you can reside if you do not want to handle the commute

pros: Nice people, nice facilities, personal development
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Regulatory Affairs Specialist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: the only reason I have managed to stay 2 years at Abbot vascular in Santa Clara, CA is my coworkers.
cons:
Extremely top heavy. in RA organization of 40+, there are 9 directors!!! 3 left last year and only one was replaced. So yes there were 12 at one point. Last year we had 15 employees leave due to work stress. Management did not blink an eye. Handful contractors were hired and left due to poor treatment. They rather start out with new contractor vs hiring the existing ones. Maybe 4-5 permanent people were hired to fill those positions. We are told to be lean! the worker bees are expected to work 12-14 hour days because we're a global company. And if you want a promotion in 2-3 years you need to put in overtime and you might just get it. Yet compensation is at least 10-15% less than other companies.
There is also a lot of outsourcing. IT is mostly gone, you deal with people in India who are not trained properly to do their job. Clinical has been outsourced to a CRO. There is one person left in doc control! Business slows because of broken systems and lack of proper resources.

review_title: Toxic environment filled with ego and discrimination
pros: 401k, medical and dental insurances are good
cons: Incompetent management, racial and gender discrimination, poor on-boarding process, cheap attitude towards company-wide meetings and treatment of employees

review_title: All Politics, Oppressive Environment, Competence Optional
pros: Interesting projects to work on, good place for technical growth.  You can work here for a while to grow your skills if you can survive the politics.
cons:
Periodic purges of entire departments or project teams, huge pressure to meet arbitrary deadlines so upper management can get their bonuses, it is far more important to be able to talk intelligently than to produce anything of value.

Mid-management is flat-out cruel.

Much work outsourced to India which was horrible.  These guys did not share information, would intentionally mislead other engineers, and created a huge mess that was impossible to untangle.

IT department is a joke.  I don't know how many times I had to re-open a ticket that IT marked "solved" when it had not even been addressed.  Completely useless but they care only about how many problems they "solve' and not actually fixing things.

There was a period where managers were scored by how many of their direct reports made "voluntary" donations to the then-CEO's former company (United Way, I think).

pros: Benefits players key role on why most people stay
cons: Terrible hours, underpay, bad management

review_title: Experience of working at Abbott Labs
pros: The company is a solid performer that is very financially or numbers driven and provides good benefits. It is more a company to retire in rather than start a fast-paced career with (although different divisions have their own personalities). But, then that is no secret.
cons: The decision making can be slow and bureaucratic at times. Senior management does not follow a hands-off approach and will try and impose US-think to other parts of the world (even though it does not work the same). I was surprised by how little direct exposure top management has to international markets particularly in the emerging markets.

review_title: They say one thing but do another
pros: There are some great people at this company. Most locations have a great onsite cafeteria where you can purchase Abbott products at a substantial discount.
cons: Extremely disorganized organization. Management is terrible. They push cost savings and innovation but don't recognize your efforts and turn down all innovative ideas. And don't dare bring any ideas to anyone above your manager! If you do, you can pretty much kiss your job goodbye. There are many positions being outsourced so there are several foreign contractors both on and off site. There is an awful language barrier which causes inefficiencies and multiple errors. Positions are constantly being eliminated causing the work to be distributed amongst the remaining employees often resulting in 60 hour plus work weeks. In my experience, my manager was literally a complete liar. She would tell me one thing but tell my coworker the complete opposite. Certain people in management positions were placed in these positions without any management experience or training.

review_title: Colleagues are lovely, culture and atmosphere very friendly, if you just want a job to go in every day and get your wage
pros: Colleagues, benefits are good, secure company, flexi time available to some staff
cons: Salary, depends on your department for career progression, none in the department I worked in.  Impossible to get on training courses etc.  Reduce costs is the bottom line.  Expected to just know everything - no proper training, thrown into job.  A lot of temp contracts offered and employees not told till a few days before they are due to finish that they got an extension.  Some employees offered permanent contracts but on <30 hours and have fought hard to get it increased to 39 hours and cant, they are biding their time to leave and look for full time hours elsewhere.

review_title: Toxic environment - don't ever try your best or speak up or you will be thrown in the acid bath.
pros: Nice clean surrounding and beautiful environment. Good pension and benefits.
cons: Nasty toxic culture. Too many friends and relatives at high position posts hence wrong people being promoted, hence  Very poor callous management. Extremely unethical hence there are always problems with product quality....a few nasty character infest the whole establishment. Most of the people only there for the money, they don't care about the company or people's life. If you do care, you are ostracised or the people in charge will try and cause you problem as obviously their main objective is to protect their jobs and their friends and family working in the company. Nepotism Rules.There is a strong rascists culture in some people who are in charge. Not necessary Abbotts ethos but certain members in position of power most certainly are.

review_title: Not good for Retiree/retired employer. No sentiments, no feelers.
pros: Good pay master, working conditions are ok. Management is quite adjustable.
cons: No care for retiring Employees. No sympathy. They are not thinking, where Employee will go after retirement at age 58. They are not feeling for pending liabilities of their employees. Extentions are being given to their loyalists even 3-4 times.

review_title: Sales at Abbott is a great place to work, but will get more difficult in coming years
job_title: Sales Representative in North Chicago, IL
pros: Old school benefits including pension plan and profit shareing.  You don't see this much anymore.  The people are generally great.  I only recently have encountered bad relationships at work, I've been here for 4 years.  Salaries areaverage for what you do, but competitive.  The positive is that its a comfortable place to work and you get some time to spend with family as well, at least with my sales position.
cons: Very large company.  Lots of policies and beurocracy in place to deal with.  Not as much freedom as smaller companies to work how you want to work.  This industry and sector is under a lot of pressure right now from FDA and us government in general.  Democrats in office, wether thats good for the country or not,  will make it more difficult for Pharma to profit, this may make it a little more difficult to work for in the future.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: the only reason I have managed to stay 2 years at abbot vascular in Santa Clara, CA is my coworkers.
cons:
Extremely top heavy. in RA organization of 40+, there are 9 directors!!! 3 left last year and only one was replaced. So yes there were 12 at one point. Last year we had 15 employees leave due to work stress. Management did not blink an eye. Handful contractors were hired and left due to poor treatment. They rather start out with new contractor vs hiring the existing ones. Maybe 4-5 permanent people were hired to fill those positions. We are told to be lean! the worker bees are expected to work 12-14 hour days because we're a global company. And if you want a promotion in 2-3 years you need to put in overtime and you might just get it. Yet compensation is at least 10-15% less than other companies. 
There is also a lot of outsourcing. IT is mostly gone, you deal with people in India who are not trained properly to do their job. Clinical has been outsourced to a CRO. There is one person left in doc control! Business slows because of broken systems and lack of proper resources.

review_title: Mostly a good place to work
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Lake Bluff, IL
pros:
If you work at the Lake County hq, there are lots of benefits (e.g. museum admission, discounted childcare on site). Other benefits: health insurance, 401k are alright. Adoption assistance and tuition reimbursement are also perks for people that need them. Pension is definitely a plus, and you're vested after 5 years. Profit sharing is not much, but still a nice end of year bonus. You get more if you get to a certain grade level, from what I've heard. 
May depend on the manager but all the people I've worked with are mostly very flexible with work/life schedule, which is the biggest pro for me. Overall, a stable career and a good working environment with decent benefits.
cons: Typical cons with a huge company. Big projects can result in poor communication between teams. Hard to move around. Career growth is slow. Still many employees from older generation, who are retiring soon and the company isn't hiring enough young employees. Too many contractors who do not get the same benefits and pay, and thus lowering morale.

pros:
Trusted with important projects, even as a recent college grad. 
Never challenged because of gender. 
Opportunities for growth. 
Can change careers within the same company since there are so many divisions of Abbott.
cons:
Work locations are always one hour from where you actually want to live. ("Chicago" location is about an hour from the actual city of Chicago... and I'm not talking about an hour from the Loop, Temecula is in a desert over an hour away from San Diego, "Dallas" location is 45 min from Dallas, etc). This could be a pro for people who don't like cities. 
It's also an old company so some people are resistant to change (Cue, "this is how we've always done it"), which can add a considerable amount of time to project timelines. 
Senior leader's goals are tethered to monetary bonuses leading to a lot of pressure on their direct reports to deliver (even when the direct reports did not have any input on the deadlines for such goals).

pros: Exponential growth and pension after 5 years, if you last that long...
cons:
Everything else:
1) ADC tries to market itself as the innovative health tech company of Silicon Valley. Don’t buy it because its culture and benefit cannot be compared to other big tech companies. The work culture here is toxic. People gossip like it is part of their work responsibilities. 
2) Many people have stayed here for a very long time and don’t bother to contribute to the work anymore (a few still do and work very hard) but for those who don’t, they spend 1/3 of their time bothering coworkers and chat loudly, 1/3 of their time surfing on the internet looking at Facebook or watching football games, 1 hour lunch, and then done for the day. Why is the company still wasting money paying these people’s salary? And don’t get sucked in by their pension plan. You only get pension after working here for 5 years, if you can last that long.
3) They are trying hard to recruit and retain young blood since many are reaching the retirement age here, which is 50. For the young folks who are considering join or just joined, don’t stay here for too long. Grass is greener outside of ADC.

pros: Pay is fair and benefits are fantastic.
cons:
The leadership in the company lacks morals and ethics. This reflects on their decision-making, how the company is run and how people are managed. Heavy workload for lower level employees. They do not respect work life balance. Employees are encouraged/expected to work long hours. They make sudden decisions and promote incompetent people just because they have tenure or they rubbed someone in higher mgt. the right way.

Leadership is weak, but very well paid. Management is focused on keeping their heads low, staying out of trouble, and protecting their budgets. Plenty of incompetent managers. Head-counts decreased or put on hold, although doing well financially. Work environment is typical of Big Pharma. Drink the Kool-Aid and get along with everyone and you should do fine. 

“(What can we do?)” This is a typical response by my superior - she would rather avoid decision-making, controversy and doing the right thing, in order to preserve her own job. She lacks the backbone.

pros: Everyone is really nice and they are friendly people.
cons: The pace is really slow.  Projects often take years to complete and along the way, there is tons of documentation that is meticulously reviewed.  There are ZERO opportunities for learning and growth.  Management will try to keep you doing the same thing over and over if you do it right the first time.  My advice is to do poorly on the projects you do not like and to do a good job on the projects you would like to be involved in.  On a personal level, management kept leading me on telling me that there will be a chance for moving up on the company, by it was not true.  Salary is not that great either.  Projects are often mismanaged and deadlines are often missed because of the poor structure of the project activities.  Overall, my experience was poor, but it depends on which area you are working.  I have heard great things about other departments within AMO.

pros: Abbott Point of Care is a small division of Abbott, so you have the opportunity for exposure to many facets of the business and levels of the organization.  It is an opportunity-rich environment.  Compensation is quite competitive for similar positions within the industry.  Opportunities for growth within the division are limited, but if you are willing to relocate there are a tremendous amount of opportunities across Abbott.
cons: The division lets people go at least once a year making the organization always in the midst of change.  Employees are always wondering and speculating about who is next and when the next layoff will be.  In my career I have never seen so many people let go and so often.

review_title: You Get Back How Much You Put In
pros: Abbott has a strong sense of family and community. Everyone is professional and polite. Even the rudest person you work with is not completely unreasonable. The pay is slightly above average. Hours are generally 45 - 50 hours a week. It is easy to build a strong network and build up your resources for success if you make an effort to do so. Your overall experience is highly dependent on your manager, the team you work with and the network you build.
cons: Outsourced work is a hit or miss. On one end they could be the best employee to work with. On the other end of the spectrum, they are unprofessional, rude, barely know English and prepare work that you have to redo yourself. Outsourced work needs better training to provide quality standardized deliverables. Also many people have no idea why they're doing what they're doing. They're just going through the motions and it can create a lot of repetitive tasks and extra work for no reason. It can create a sense of non-value added work and under appreciation at times.

review_title: Great benefits, incredibly toxic environment and backwards thinking upper management
pros: Great salary (note - there is a wide range for each grade, make sure you negotiate), 3 weeks vacation with option to purchase 1 extra week, pension plan, good 401k match. Lots of opportunities as this is a huge company. Subsidized cafeterias so food is relatively cheap
cons: Where to start... incredibly toxic work environment (managers feel comfortable mocking employees for taking time off) zero work from home policy with no plans to change, they work you from sunup to sun down, buildings are outdated, and everything is one big political cesspool. Not a good place to be if you want to move up in one specific department - you have to hop around a lot (or wait forever to be promoted). To note, I have heard that the sales teams are the opposite and actually nice to work for, but every other department I encountered had the same gripes. There continues to be a mass exodus from my department.

review_title: Build a career that will out last you - consider working with Abbott Laboratories
pros: Excellence is a way of life - while not there in every aspect, the quest for excellence is ever before us - great products to represent - currently we have a super management team - innovation leaders - balanced across a number of units - strong financial performance - leader in the pharma sector - honorable work, providing products that improve and save lives - great people, great culture, solid core competencies, management cares what employees think, regular feedback opportunities that are evaluated and lead to positive changes, management is not intimidated about doing the smaller jobs along with employees, strong culture of teamwork across the board.
cons: Promotion without relocation is difficult - long hours to achieve excellence - legal and ethics guidelines have made working with physicians more difficult - oversight paperwork has become a major factor in the jobs.

review_title: A genuine employer with good reputation, but attention on some management staff
pros: - Excellent Reputation and Products mixed with very interesting projects within strategy, sourcing, technology improvement. A very nice work environment with best in class facility. In general competent and helping colleagues within a very ambivalent, inter-cultural (though 90% European, from Italy to the north) environment.
cons:
It has a lot of long-term acting employees >15 yrs but some of the newly hired managers (<2 yrs) do not fit from behavior and account to the environment in Basel. Most interviewing staff are not really experience in HR recruitment and hiring and this might result in having not screen the skills adequately. From 10, 4 Directors and Senior Directors seem to be "Cowbows" and very self-oriented.  Spirit missing. 
- Unfortunately the cantine does not provide an over the average food, often missing choices or poor salad and vegi bar.
- Too much politics

review_title: Abbott - A place to learn, grow, and build a career
job_title: Market Research Analyst in Abbott Park, IL
pros:
Abbott is an employer that values its workers, patients, and stakehodlers it serves. At the undegraduate and graduate level, Abbott has management development programs in the ares of HR, Finance, Marketing, Science, and research. While it is hard to generalize about Abbott, due to its size, I would say that most individuals are go getters. We have many individuals with Top 20 MBAs all over the company. 

Abbott's diverse businesses do give ample opportunity for career movement. Also, opportunities working abroad are available.
cons: If its size is a plus, it can be a downside too. Many times it is hard to get things done with multiple layers. However, Abbott does realize this and attempts to eliminate red tape. It is a far commute from Chicago if you live in the city. Pay is not on scale with other pharma or companies in the Northern Burbs considerdering its great benefits package and overall benefits

review_title: Perfect for corporate career minded individuals
pros: Good pay, good benefits, 3 week vacation to start.  Save as much as you can in the 401k.  Work experience is good if you have a good management team in your department.  If you enjoy playing the 'performance review game', you'll really love it.  Seriously, if you want a good, solid career, this is  the place.  Keep in mind that you won't be given a lot of creativity or innovation.
cons: Too much corporate gamesmanship at the mid level management.  Often times your manager's goals are to move people up are a priority over the actual project itself.  Too much emphasis on performance reviews and creating goals just for the sake of aving goals.  Company is old and seems to discourage creativity.  Company is in the process of splitting off the research division and big changes are coming. Look for the pension plans to disappear in the future.

pros: Competitive Pay & benefits.  Knowledgeable people.
cons:
Terrible work-life balance.
No tele-commuting.
Results rewarded with greater workload.
Device industry is retracting
Innovation deficient / risk averse.
Cliquey/old boy's network.

review_title: Great People Locally - poor elsewhere - IT disasterous
pros: The staff workers I supported as a contractor for a local office were wonderful, dedicated to their jobs and going the extra mile.  Plus they were FUN to be with, always an internal office game from time to time ( a hoola-hoop contest one day and a totally off the wall rubber duck hunt).  Top notch.  That said, anybody above their office in management was questionable to a degree.
cons: Outsourcing.  Period.  This move to shift IT, accounting and other functions to Wipro is a functional disaster.  It hobbled these fine people in doing their jobs efficiently and accounting is costing Abbott money.  And forget information technology, doesn't exist anymore.  The pay was poor for scale and the decisions were mostly brain-dead dumb.  Some individuals still exist in structure, but not many and the GSD help desk takes days to route a ticket from user to me

review_title: Decent company, good benefits, tenuous future
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The individual contributors are enthusiastic, kind, and generally compassionate people, who smile at  others and do their best to enjoy their workday.
cons:
Decision-making is precarious and uncertain to those that drive the actual results of the organization, the individual contributors.  Senior  management is covert in their decision-making and severely compromised by Ego.  The organization has been steadily stripping away it's R&D and Mfg. workforce with seemingly calculated (bi-quarterly) layoffs since 2012.   

Merit is based on ones' relationship with management and the Perception of productivity, not one's actual productivity.  

This organization is becoming crippled by bureaucracy, perhaps most evident through the Quality System, which is devastatingly handicapped by layers complex electronic record-keeping and seemingly redundant approval steps.  Also, the structure of each document is very long-winded and lacks conciseness.  Not sure if FDA even reads this stuff.....

job_title: Senior Process Development Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
CardioMEMS is a fantastic product and I am proud to have worked on it. 

Personnel in the factory are hard working and intelligent.
cons:
During 2 leadership changes over the  course of 3 years, Abbott has no idea how SJM culture is hindering Cardiomems progress.. 

Management cannot figure out how to make this product robust because they are treating a MEMS factory like a Catheter Integration factory. 

Transplanted leadership treats dedicated personnel like they are beneath them, which is the reason many good employees are leaving this site.

review_title: Check your ego at the door
job_title: Project Manager in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Chance to get experience working for a global and diverse Healthcare organization.  Opportunity to work in a variety of business units from medical device to pharma.  Good networking opportunites with other employees and through professional associations.  You'll also get exposure to working with government agencies and industry organizations.
cons: Quite a few senior executives, VPs, and especially the CEO, adopt the work approach of:  "It's all about me and my stock options."  Businesses often pitted against each other fighting over internal resources.  Bi-polar attitude towards financial measurements and work accountability standards.  One day you'd be investing in growth, hiring people or expanding operations, and the next day you needed to outsource everything, freeze job requisitions and reduce headcount.  Work/life balance difficult as hours were long.

pros: People are very motivated to help those with diabetes.  Nice location.  Great pay and benefits (bonus, stock, pension).  Better than average job security.  Interesting products that help people.  A decent place to work overall.
cons: Poor teamwork.  Groups are set against each other, and within groups there are favorites and rejects.  This is not an open environment:  yes-men will flourish.  If you are cautious or highlight concerns instead of successes you are often punished.  Oversight is ineffective - nobody asks questions in reviews, from bottom to top.  (I would be punished if I asked probing questions so I am silent.)

job_title: Senior Talent Acquisition Specialist in Lake Bluff, IL
pros: Great job and company stability, interesting/ impactful work, great Benefits (includes both 401K AND Pension Plan!), professional, fun, diverse, and collaborative culture, along with viable  internal mobility, cutting-edge, innovative and positively impactful medical/healthcare devices, systems, etc.
cons: They need to open up a Downtown Chicago location and/or allow for more flexibility to work from home(so as to attract high-quality talent who live in or near the city and who DON’T want to waste time and money commuting all the way up to the North Shore or North Chicago)!

review_title: Reduction of workforce just to outsource the positions
job_title: Order Entry Administrator in Columbus, OH
pros: I absolutely loved working there. I work live balance was amazing. I managements was great.  The salary was wonderful.  I could not have asked for better coworkers.
cons: Constant lay offs. In my department in particular, the laid us all off. Only to outsource our position to a temporary agency in Detroit to pay those employees $9.00 per hour.  Meanwhile the bigwigs in the coming still received their bonuses and merit raise.

review_title: If you are a woman of color learn to be submissive
pros: If you are a male or female who enjoys harassing women of color, then is the right place for you. If you enjoy spending your team's budget without measuring ROI because you lack experience and skills, then this is the right place for you.  To excel here you must be a proficient liar and exceptional at posturing. Directors and VPs abuse their employees because the culture encourages and HR supports such behavior.
cons: If you are a woman of color, do not dare to ask for growth you will be labelled rude by the male manager. If you are a woman of color, your male manager will take credit for your work and label you unprofessional if you ask him any questions. Women who have survived here embody the abusive trait of their male counter part. Discrimination of women of color is everyday busy, ER and HR support harassment of women with color and instead of addressing the issue they ask the women of color to leave the company. If you report harassment, you will be let go without reason.

review_title: Probably a good company for permanent employees, but temporary workers get shafted.
pros:
The pay is decent and, if you can get a permanent role, there seems to be great job security. I've also heard the benefits are consistent with a larger company (medical options, retirement savings, paid time off).

I hear Abbott is a good company to work for, just not Abbott Diabetes.
cons:
You are a drone in a very large cog. My role was very specialized, which got boring. My manager was awful and, despite bad reviews year after year, will never be let go. 

The company hires temporary employees for a good portion of the positions, and will often keep them for 2 years. After two years, the employee is required to take a 30 day unpaid leave before they can return to work. I'm surprised by how often this actually happens... why not just hire your employees on a permanent basis? Don't they want to retain their talent?

The management team will also pass their projects on to the temp employees to complete, then pass the work off as their own.

review_title: Good place to work if given the right opportunities
job_title: Purchasing Agent in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Outstanding benefits, offices everywhere, ability to work with all sorts of people, learn a lot, many employees are older and have lots of valuable experience to share, robust transport to and from Metra, involved in community (charitable), great seminars to learn about operations/life issues, very good/inexpensive food in cafeterias, significant support of development programs, options for tuition reimbursement, established mentorship program, access to Abbott Credit Union (ALEC)
cons: Culture: inflexible, non-meritocracy, significant promotion of 'friends', as a young person if not from the PDP (development program) then frequently passed over by management for any type of opportunity, poor morale, large contractor workforce contributes to poor morale, company's aggressive restructuring frequently leads to unexpected layoffs (someone who is there one day is gone the next with no plan to continue their work and co-workers must immediately pick up slack), lots of surprise management announcements, underperformers tolerated to a large extent, politics, bureaucracy

pros:
Good pay and benefits
Flexible schedule (Like most companies offer)
cons:
The corporate culture and hierarchy is a network of who you know and not one of competencies.  The management is a parade of autocratic and persuasive leaders who definitely need ongoing emotional intelligence training.  Quite honestly, movement up the organization chart is severely impeded if you are not one of the manager's faves or if your manager fears your success over his/hers.

Continuous corporate restructuring and 'strategic objectives' impose the threat of reductions in force that loom over this corporate giant like a hawk swooping down on its prey.  After many years of employment, my advice to any job/career seeker is to avoid this soul-sucking, Dow Jones focused, profit over people organization.

job_title: Labeling Coordinator in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Variety of  products (pharmaceutical or nutrition)
cons:
You can stay in same position for years and it does not matter if you want to grow outside your country (annual PEX) , at the end, your boss in your country or even at Division (main offices) don´t support you. On the other hand, in Mexico are a lot of "semi professional" with the opposite Abbott thoughts, policies and QA processes and they stop you not matter what even broken them.
In my country the company is good to learn but not for growing in different positions.
Marketing in country is not doing their job, they only reports sell but they are not able to create a good promotional campaign to sell more or to provide benefits.

pros: Solid Fortune 500 company with tons of resources, quality products, marketing, and training to back you up. You will become a better Sales Rep and Businessperson. Numerous condition specific products and healthcare call points that prepare you for better sales opportunities in the future.
cons: Culture changed very quickly in the past 5 years. What once was stated from management as "you manage your territory", it is now micro managed for you by them. Big Pharma mind-set is now the way of life. Get on the "Blue Train" or be gone. Older Reps with a record of success are now targeted for dismissal if not seen as "dynamic" or willing to roll-over and learn corporate's new tricks. Pay is good but below that of Abbott Primary Care samplers and caterers. Tons of busy work to be done "before/after-selling-time" and ride-withs that in reality take away from face time with customers. Not fun anymore.

job_title: Outpatient Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Meaningful company mission - Bettering people’s lives through  the power of good health. 

They really take care of you here: 
- 24 years old entry level sales $70k- 80k base + $25k bonus 
- 7% profit sharing 
- Company car 
- 401k 5% $-$ match
- 3 weeks of PTO, 3 floating holidays 
- Health, dental, and vision insurance the first day you start

Clear territories and sales expectations with competent leaders.
cons: In my opinion it was really hard to get into Abbott. Make sure your resume stands out with higher education and have clear achievement measurements on your resume if you’re in sales.

review_title: Needs some focus and a vision
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Pays well. 
Many competent, driven and nice people.
cons: At the time I left the company it was the typical corporate BS. This division needed to create a better corporate culture, find its vision, believe it, sell it to the employees and stick with it. Management has less attention and focus than my ADHD son....  **SQUIRREL**  ... sorry, where was I.... But like many of the large corporations, the employee was one more cog in the wheel. This division had high hopes at one time of breaking out of impersonal, high pressure, big corporate way of doing things - but lost it along the way.

pros: Great Benefits, Great Pay, Great Employees, Great Customers, a Few Great Managers, old days were fun, exciting and fulfilling, most advanced products in the industry,
cons: Poor Employee Management, Poor Performance Review, Work Environment is hostile, Over-worked to the point where its hardly manageable, Other dept's are under-worked to the point that distractions are the majority of your day, Poor Managers that resent their talent and gossip more then they would perform, antiquated systems and overly complicated processes to compensate for them, Fanciful offices for Senior Management

review_title: As Guidant, We Were Great at Manufacturing and R&D. Under Abbott, We're Being Sucked Dry To Be Kicked to the Curb Later
pros:
Location close to Freeway, Shopping and Restaurants.
Co-workers.
cons:
Understaffed in virtually all support functions
Off-shoring/Outsourcing jobs - no long term future, employees not valued
Frequent employee RIFs to keep up quarterly numbers preceded by [unexplainable] upper management promotions
Inability to challenge bad decisions
Planning gets in the way of execution
Business Excellence is a joke - we talk the talk, but we don't walk the walk
CAPA process used far too frequently as a project management tool
No technical ladder for growth

review_title: A good place to work for
job_title: Financial Analyst ( Junior ) in Abbott Park, IL
pros: The benefits are really great and room for career development/perhaps advancement. Also there are many affinity groups so you can find people you share hobbies with. There are many divisions within the company so you are able to move very easily within the company if you build the right networks. They offer a career development program which for entry level employees can be beneficial and teach them more about the overall Corporation. A lot of the work force is currently retiring so there will most likely be many opportunities for promotion. They have a shuttle so if you live downtown then can easily commute. The Clara Abbott Foundation helps a lot of people who are in need; I have heard of them doing some great things for people at no cost.
cons: Micromanagement at least in departments in my area. The area where it is located is pretty much isolated from the bigger cities.

job_title: Multiple Positions in Casa Grande, AZ
pros: This is a very competitive company great perks and benefit. They give you a lot of training.  They are very community helpful in so many area's outgoing to help other community projects. Fellow employee's are very outgoing. Company very high on Health of its employee's and getting them healthy. Very high standards on the safety and wellness of their staff and the products they produce.
cons: Hard to get hired here took over 3 years as a contractor to be hired. The applications you put in are over looked many times and people are passed up in many job area's. Much of the hiring is based off of selective favoritism or friendships.

review_title: Abbott Vascular is a leader in interventional cardiology who is reinventing itself with new products which have real value to patients and the healthcare systems around the world.
pros: In the challenging healthcare business, AV is focused on new strategies to lead the healthcare transformation to higher value offerings. It is not the easy win environment any more, so there are big challenges to all employees at all levels in the company. The culture is good, but needs to get better.
cons: Everyone complains about being risk averse, then waits for someone to tell them what to do. Some of the management is very good, others are slow to change. Most employees at all levels are very talented (especially after successive layoffs), but much of the ability goes untapped. Management and staff need to align on strategy (it is starting now) and this business can be much better through increased sales and the innovative growth which follows.

review_title: Empty the ocean with a spoon...
job_title: Customer Service Administrator in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Decent salary, little perks like a free breakfast once a month, great co-workers, that's about it, any other benefits or perks will be lower than similar companies, including holidays. Long (2 months + ) training but disconnected from your real job.
cons:
Micromanagement, unbalanced workload distribution as the ones who are doing not much are doing less and less while the ones who are doing too much are doing more and more, no upwards review/feedback only archaic and school-like management system. 
Unrealistic workload, targets and performance ratings.  Robotic time measurement system not mitigated by a human being. Don't expect recognition for your hard work, it's part of how you've been managed.

Huge turnover in dysfunctional Customer Service Team, being 6 months in CS is already being a veteran there. Culture of blame and the company do not take care of its employees whatsoever at least at the CS level. I witnessed myself a manager having a laugh literally (thus not productively working I suppose!) 80%+ of her workday!! And still be back the following day...

review_title: Best to use employment at Abbott as short term stepping stone.
pros: Good name recognition on CV, solid group of co-workers.  Good opportunity to work on global projects or take on extra tasks for personal knowledge.
cons: Disfunctional department & upper-level management, with little to zero company investment into employees. Questionable internal finances and huge budget cuts after AbbVie company split. Poor investment and little understanding of what is needed to succeed in emerging markets. Overall I get the feeling they are not doing well in the global market but managed to keep numbers looking good for stockholders... at expense of cutting in the wrong places.

job_title: Associate Validation Analyst in Hollywood, FL
pros: Diversity, team work, opportunities for growth, great benefits and stable career. I think this company has helped me learn a lot. In the time I have been working here I find I learn something new everyday. I love the building. Coming in to work everyday is pleasant and the location is definitely a plus. The overall work atmosphere is great. Lots of diversity and you meet people from all walks of life. Management is very good, fair and accessible.  I love the product we sell too. It's rewarding to know the group works very hard and is devoted to delivering a quality product that makes labs and facilities run more efficiently. The co workers are friendly and will help with training new employees and answer any questions.
cons: During busy times it is needed to give extra hours including weekends or working from home. But the company is very good with rewarding employees and recognizing those who put in the extra effort. In the end it's worth the extra time put in.

pros: Employees are open about how poor the state of affairs are. Good products but older generation. How can SJM acquisition save stents?
cons: After company wide massive IT layoffs & disconnected enterprise systems, expect to call 800 # for any and every need & be put in a queue. HR, finance are scant, expect to call Chicago for a lot of help. Not strategic & not cohesive management leads to multiple wasted efforts and last minute rush on all efforts. No training for new managers, no on-boarding assistance or requirements, everyone fend for yourself. In-fighting & low morale completely tolerated.  Overall, archaic systems, poor middle & upper management, lagging behind in product development. Look elsewhere.

review_title: Great company to work for, great life/work balance, with a collegial feeling. Subpar HR department.
job_title: QA Engineer in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Great people make Abbott a great company to work for. Benefits package is very competitive. There are some opportunities to move in internally. Company also has a leadership program that seems to attract very bright individuals. There are people that have been over 20 years with the company and have tremendous institutional memory, and they are willing to help newbies. If you are working in project management, there are some limited opportunities to move between Abbott Park and smaller divisions. Good work / life balance.
cons: Performance appraisal process does not account for much. Human Resources not the best department - or maybe I have not seen many HR departments before. Some politics are to be expected.

job_title: Sales Management Trainee in New Delhi
pros:
1>Good pay master
2>Brand 
3>Good to start your career ,if you want to grow in sales.
cons:
1>They treat you like an expendable asserts.
2>For the name sake its a MNC ,but let me assure you Its actually worst than India Leading pharma companies like USV and SUN or DRL.
3>Being a MBA doesn't give you respect here ,they treat you like a Medical Rep.
4>No career progression untill unless you want to grow in sales (What is the use of MBA then)
5> Nothing much to learn,all you need to do is plead to doctors for prescriptions. 
6>HR doesnt care about you and leave you in alms of your first line manager who is nothing but science grad with zero logic and sales attitude.
8>No way you can enter Marketing like PMT profile as they don't want you there .
9>Advice to MBA grads,please don't enter this hell untill unless Money matters to you ,go for profile.

review_title: Evaluate the team you will work with and for before accepting an offer
pros: Lots of free time, not many cases.  Pay and benefits are good, just make sure you know what everyone else is making to get fair base because they will make a low offer saying that is as much as they can give, which is not true.
cons: Poor training, no collaboration or positive encouragement among team, management is virtually non existent and does not listen when problems arise and they set the tone for the negative culture by speaking poorly about all of their employees to other employees

review_title: Good money if you can survive the internal politics and influence groups ..
pros: Good base, bonus, benefits package. hey do not scrimp on projects or events once they are approved. Great camaraderie if you can get in to one of the influence groups. They are getting up in their market position, so things are looking good in general.
cons: Have to go through hoops to get budgets approved. Never know who is working behind you to undermine your position or efforts. Can be very nit-picky in and use that against you, when appropriate - while others seem to get away with blatant lies and miss-directions. ALthough their market position is improving, the overall market is drastically hit with recent events ... so not a good industry segment to be in right now unless they change their business model.

pros:
1.  Clear commitment from senior leadership to not only TALK change but drive it and INVEST in it--Budgets are being allocated to back the initiatives that management preaches.
2.  High-energy, fun workplace--there's a genuine cameraderie and a sense that your work is my work too here.  I LIKE my coworkers!
3.  Exciting and innovative products--yeah, for a while AV seemed to be resting on its past achievements, but the Absorb line, the expanding Xience lines, and the St. Jude acquisition mean the work here is anything but boring!,
cons:
1.  It's still an old-line medical device company in a lot of ways, so business transformation takes time and patience and sustained commitment to the vision.
2.  More conservative than some of our competitors in what we say in public, so it's occasionally frustrating to see us hold back where competitors don't.

pros:
Great products, passionate people, quality management and processes very good.
Not bad pay higher up, not good lower down. Good healthcare.
cons:
Bullying, and people in Senior positions because of who they know regardless of being completely incompetent, even in the most basic skills.  HR not trusted at all by employees. Don't complain because they will stitch you up.

Poor development of less senior employees. Lucky of you go on one training course in 5 years.

Mass Abbott redundancies of long term employees, and redundancy pay only statutory minimum. So for example 20 years service will only give you a couple of thousand pounds. HR can be very sinister and intimidating.

Can be very cliquey and people can be excluded and minorities discriminated against. Senior management will often support this discrimination.

review_title: If you absolutely must have a job...
pros: Not many, a check every two weeks, medical benefits, average to less than average salaries.
cons: Horrible mgrs, their mantra is to eliminate all overtime for non-exempt employees; hired at below market rate pay; Abbott eliminated bonus (except for mgrs, imagine that) and the pension plan, across the board, as well as making the vesting on 401k funds 5 years! It is certain managers do not have these restrictions, and get nice bonuses for "lowering costs" at the expense of employee benefits and loyalty.  I've had no experience with SJM before Abbott, but this is one of the worst corporate experiences I have had.  I am working on an exit strategy every day, and so are many others.

pros: Training was excellent. Products are excellent.
cons:
This place was an HR nightmare, it’s hard to know where to start. 

Career advancement: Non degree/No IBHRE employees were promoted above extremely talented MBA/cross trained individuals due to their openness to partake in morally questionable activities. Married sales reps sleeping with physicians and lab staff for cases seemed to be the only  standard my region had. 

Sexual Harassment: Rampant in my territory. Management would turn a blind eye. Sales reps would wine and dine doctors multiple times a week against policy and then follow it by taking the doctor to the strip club. It comes as no surprise with encouraged activities like these from senior sales reps that when covering these physicians, they see no probably grabbing your butt in a case because who would you complain to? The guy who took the physician to a strip club!? Very shady. 

Harassment: Constant degrading from senior sales reps and management. Sr sales reps would throw clinicals under the bus constantly to protect their own butts. Furthermore they would belittle them while stealing the clinicals efforts as their own to win physician approval. 

Disclaimer: I’m sure not every region is like this.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Forest, CA
pros:
Can work autonomously with little micro management
A place you can develop skills and be innovative
Fair pay and excellent benefits, working environment
Talented staff and most are highly skilled and easy to work with.
cons:
Upper management too far removed from staff responsibilities
Some departments are silo'd and are hard to get a hold of, so cross-functional teamwork can be a challenge
Constant reorganizational change resulting in job an responsibility uncertainty
Lack of process or standards in the form of documentation.  Had to rely solely on Tribal Knowledge, which wasn't always available due to high turnover in staff.  Achieving written documentation is hard when everything is contained in 'living documents' that are affected by constant change.

review_title: Great place to start and end your career, but there has been a recent decline in employee satisfaction.
pros: Abbott has wonderful entry level programs for internships and professional development programs. Most managers allow for flexible schedules/remote work on occasion. The benefits are very good for health and retirement.
cons: Abbott is doing a lot of outsourcing to reign in costs. This has brought down morale across the organization. The company does not do anything innovative in terms of improving work culture or employee perks. Vacation allowance starts off average when compared to other large companies, but you do not get additional time until you have been with the company over 11 years.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Burlington, WI
pros: Global, diversified, many opportunities, **benefits (pension, 401k, AND profit sharing), many good people, many good managers
cons: Company no longer cares about employees as it once did. Senior management concerned with short-term perceptions and managing their careers more than managing the business.  Despite making various lists of great companies to work for, Abbott is not as well respected as it use to be. The company business model is to purchase other companies with products that can be marketed vs innovation.  Would not recommend working at Abbott in IT.  Corporate IT culture is VERY toxic since 2015.  CIO is not well respected.  Expect continued outsourcing and talent loss.

review_title: I worked with incredible people, learned a lot about the business and gained exceptional knowledge in my field.
job_title: Legal Assistant in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Fantastic learning opportunities, great career building experience, great cafeterias, walking paths, work life balance in most jobs is pretty good, a lot of wonderful people, a lot of diversity and a lot of mentoring opportunities. They also have gyms and childcare facilities on site.
cons: Some of the typical big corporate cons are just that change takes a long time, there is a little bit of red tape. It may be hard to get recognized for your achievements in such a big company, it just depends on your department and management. I felt like it was taking a long time to move up in my role, the requirements for promotions were very very vague. I honestly would have stayed til retirement given different circumstances. I really can't imagine a better group of people to work with for my first corporate job.

review_title: Could be the best of the pharmas if it put in a new leader before it's too late.
pros: It's a leader in the pharma field.  If you get on the "fast track", the sky is the limit...however, it's so huge, that most folks get swallowed up.  Great benefit package.
cons: As with many large corps, age discrimination is a fact of life.  Unless you are in upper middle management, don't expect to work here if you are over 55.  It's so wrapped up in regulation that it's difficult to get anything done.  Upper management has a habit of putting "touchy-feely" crap in place to hide the blemishes from those who will buy into the scam.

review_title: Still a good job, but not a longterm career.
pros: Abbott seems to be a very stable, conservative company.  The company has done a nice job diversifying its portfolio.  Abbott is a respected name with customers.
cons:
Most of the cons are due to issues bigger than Abbott.  The problems with my job would be similar with most pharmaceutical companies.  There is little job security due to changes in healthcare and the poor economy.  In addition, the selling environment continues to deteriorate, which leads to little, if any, job satisfaction.  Abbott isnt a bad place to work, but selling pharmaceuticals to primary care is not the best place to be in my opinion.

Abbott does have a number of divisions that are appealing, but movement is clogged right now due to downsizing in the company.

review_title: Started out very positive and full of opportunities. Now there are zero chances for advancement.
job_title: Quality Assurance Coordinator in Crystal Lake, IL
pros: Great benefits! Health, vision, dental, 401K, SRP. Benefits kick in on day 1. Great amount of vacation when you start.
cons: They have 1 manager to cover multiple departments. Some positions are literally revolving door. The Management here definitely takes care of their favorites. They lack the ability to solve problems. Instead they look for the quick fix or band aid solutions. They don't recognize the good work you do. They don't include everyone in their reindeer games. Only the ones they see everyday. That brings down morale. They are big on Line of Sight communications. In other words they  only communicate to you when they see you. Which in many cases is very little.

review_title: Too many generals and not enough soldiers!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Pretty good benefits and salary! Depending on how your boss chooses to manager, family-work life ratio is great. There is always work to do so no chance for boredom. Workout facility on-site and depending on your location, working remotely from home is available.
cons: No promotion opportunities, even cross-divisional. Too much management but not enough workers to to the real actual work. Morale is low because employees are being stretched doing duties outside of their expertise and core jobs. Smart minds there but unawareness of simple smart business practices. Selfish atmosphere and inter-department conflicts on regulations and procedure practices. A lot of finger-pointing when ball is dropped and lack of accountability.

review_title: Excited to start,but not a great experience
job_title: Field Service Engineer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Large fortune 100 company. Many nice people willing to help you out. Dallas, Texas headquarters, need I say more?
cons: Your performance is measured against a lot of metrics much of which is out of your control. Company is performance driven by by these arbitrary metrics. Hospitalization is expensive, and coinsurance is as well. The training is terrible, and you will be left hanging in front of customers as you learn how to fix instruments on the fly. Typical corporate culture, focus is strictly on earnings and shareholders. Your everyday tools are outdated, especially your handheld  device to close calls. You'll spend many hours needlessly waiting on software.

job_title: Operations Manager in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Improving people's lives.  Even though Abbott is well its behind competitors in fair compensation, the pharma industry pays well.  Abbott has a great benefits package.
cons: Fair compensation, all talk and no walk, senior and executive management incompetence.  Layoffs continue to happen-- silently.  Unless you get a dynamite manager, there is NO SUCH THING as work/life balance.  You either work 80 hours or find another job.

review_title: Satisfactory, however M&A had significant impact on long term employee security and growth opportunities.
job_title: Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative in Annapolis, MD
pros: Good pay, bonus adequate, profit sharing, pension,
cons: M&A created far too large a sales force with far too few products to promote and too many reps on teams in territories with inadequate pipeline to support the sales force led to 40% reduction in force in 2011.  Many tenured highly productive reps at or near pension were let go along with the 900 reps positions that were eliminated, while other non productive less tenured reps were retained.  Bell curve was enough to avoid legal actions.  Abbotts business is no longer patient or personnel focused, simply the bottom line for upper management and their focus on retaining their hghly overcompensated positions. Dismanagement abounds.

review_title: Once a great company but now a horrible place
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: AV offers a somewhat competitive salary, 401K and a company funded pension. The products are quality products that improve or save lives.
cons:
Losing in both Coronary and Endovascular 
No clear strategy. Employees just do as told so the best ideas based on the best marketing intelligence are often not executed
So many personnel changes in the last few years. Senior Level/High Salary employees were laid off to reduce salary payouts. The beginning of the end started when a few key senior leaders were let go.   A lot of sleeping around and associated drama in the organization. "Drama!!!"

review_title: If you want to end up having career stagnation,this is the right place
pros: Sprawling office , although it is a glorified jail since long hours is a norm
cons: Long exhausting meetings, 90% of working hours wasted in meetings. Support functions leave on time irrespective of whether work is done or not. Very tough place for marketing. Huge culture of nepotism. If you aren't liked by the big guys you will be kicked out. You have to say yes to everything. The meagre increment every year is laughable. Top management is paid like Kings n bottom n middle management given peanuts. Growth is restricted to only and only boss pleasers. If u please immediate boss and your super boss doesn't like you then you pack your bags. No room for new ideas and change. So in short if you want a toxic culture with zero personal life and income then please join this organization . Hr is also toxic since they help top management in removing good people.

review_title: Benefits are good, but no career opportunity unless you start with the RDP program
pros: When I started with Abbott I had a great manager who listened to the team and fostered personal development. Then the reorg came...
cons: In Jan 2018 there was a reorganization that closed the office I was located in, I was given the option to move to Minneapolis and continue my employment.  Moving to Minneapolis, my quality of life would have done and my cost of living would have gone up. When talking to the new leadership I was basically dismissed and it was their way or the highway. Leadership didn't seem to want any employees who was part of the old Directors team.  The two months that were left of my employment, I came to have negative respect for this individual r and was glad I don't have to work under that leadership.

review_title: Poor Management, even worse HR department
pros: Medisense used to be a great company to work for, was a people company with great benefits, great work environment and great people! When Abbott brought Medisense out, they continued with the Medisense values, but it soon changed!!!
cons: A lot of the production managers are out for themselves, and don't care who they tread on to get themselves noticed. They have no respect for their employees, even the ones who have been working there long term (10years plus). They supposedly have a whistle blowing policy, which is totally ignored when a complaint against management is made!! Investigation only involves interviewing the manager involved, and it is their word against yours!! HR are supposed to be impartial, but are known to side with management, which is why people are not whistle blowing, because they know what the outcome will be....and they are scared. They would rather be treated like crap!!!

pros: Abbott is a great company to work for. They offer a great benefit package and they do offer the opportunity to learn and grow and move up in the company. They make a good effort to encourage a happy work environment and they offer overtime.
cons: Abbott cycles managers throughout different areas of the plant so often that the managers never fully get proficient at their role before moving onto another role. Their theory is that you dont need experience in the department you are managing to run it. It does not work because managers set unreal expectations and take time away from employees when the employee needs to explain something basic to management. Abbott's corporate culture makes it impossible to balance work and family.

pros: Abbott Labs offers great growth planning and career opportunities for those willing to relocate and sacrifice their work life balance.  They offer great benefits with stock options, 401 k matching and year end profit sharing.
cons: The cons would probably apply to any pharmaceutical company in todays market place.  What they ask of you and what you are able to produce are unrealistic.  It has become increasing difficult to see physcians and leave samples at offices.  Many have adopted a no see policy but corporate still requires you to see a predetermined amount of people.  Representatives and Managers are often left with moral delimas.  Employee satisfaction and empowerment has been long forgotten concepts.

review_title: GREAT company. Managers can be hit or miss.
pros: Above average pay and benefits (pension, matched 401k, profit sharing, annual bonus/raise, etc.). The company genuinely cares about its products and customers. I can really only speak for my division, but my coworkers are outstanding individuals with incredible amounts of knowledge in their respective fields. It's rare to find someone who isn't 100% devoted to doing quality work and satisfying their customers.
cons: While Senior Managers actually seem to be quite good overall, first level management is very hit or miss. You might end up working for an incredibly inspiring mentor or a backstabbing micromanager. This could be true for many companies, but it is VERY true here.

review_title: Good place to begin a pharma sales career
pros: It has been a long time since I've worked at Abbott, but when I was recruited by the district manager the salary was about the median for a pharma rep at the time. The benefits of course were excellent. I had a territory comprising most of urban Northern Virginia and some of Washington DC, which kept me busy. A company car was provided and AMEX card, all of the trappings of an early 1990s pharma field sales job.
cons: My district manager was very heavy handed in general-not unusual for those days, high pressure to succeed and exceed goals for my territory. Nothing I didn't expect from a Fortune 100 company manager. There was a very long, three week away-from-home training period when I first started with the company. Tests every night and again lots of pressure. If you deal with pressure well-and I did, you will be fine.

review_title: Exciting product, tough market and decision process
pros: Excellent collaboration and support throughout the organization.  Product is well respected and used throughout the healthcare market.
cons: Organization is very reactive, has opted out of IDN and GPO agreements and has no real strategy to gain traction in these areas.  Product pipeline is weak and specialists are asked to wear many hats.  Not sure the ROI for the average rep is sufficient.  Sales cycle is very long and one has to focus the attention of 3-4 different departments, work with a usually hostile lab and prove the benefit of changing their processes by implementing the APOC solution.  Lots of PI and PM work, which most are not really trained to do.

review_title: Avoid!  Terrible company with toxic culture who can't develop decent products
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Pay was fair, and pension was a nice offering (but hard to get)
cons:
Toxic work culture of managing by fear, starting from the top CEO to middle management who degrades,  insults and curses at their employees.  This is a lawsuit waiting to happen, especially with lack of diversity.  

Very little colleague camaraderie since it everyone was for themselves due to top down toxic management approach.  Leadership is untrustworthy, and can't stomach bad news (like it takes time to develop new products in a regulated space).  Do you want another consent decree from the FDA?

Was the innovator of past, but have been resting on their laurels for past decades.  Most innovators had left, and all that is left is supporting out of date technology.  

Worst professional experience of my working career and wish could take back the time

review_title: Good engineers, vicious management, oppressive environment, bureaucratic quagmire and politically treacherous
pros: Decent benefits, some nice people, mostly smart colleagues in the technical departments.
cons:
Amazingly dysfunctional IT - it is just astounding - I had to open the same work item a dozen times as they marked it completed without addressing it.
Very oppressive feeling - people seem to be scared of each other, very cliquish.
Life at ADC is more about looking smart and informed and less about producing results.
Management is treacherous, unsupportive, vicious.
They're glad to hire several contractors in India instead of engineers in California.
Lots of pressure to donate money to select charities - managers are held accountable for their departments' donations to the CEO's old company/charity.

pros:
The IT dept. is always looking at the latest management trends and tries to incorporate as much as possible.
The company values are clear, easy to identify with and make decisions within.
The R&D group is passionate about making people's lives better
The parent company works to take care of employees well.
cons:
So much change in the IT dept. makes it difficult to keep up.
Several Layoffs in the last 5 years makes employees concerned they will not have a job in 6 months.
Cost concerns have reduced training opportunities to keep skills relevant and current
IT dept opportunities for advancement are rare due to the number of higher level employees who have left and their seats have not been filled by promotions

job_title: Customer Service Professional in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: Friendly working environment,  solid products, easy computer systems to work with...

Abbott has a long history of successful business culture.  They have a very high level of professionalism, with very dedicated people.  If you hire an ex-Abbott person, you're getting someone with a lot of valuable experience.  Miles White is a very highly-rated CEO, and that plays a lot into business transactions around the world.  They have successfully made the jump from an American-based company doing business internationally, to a truly global firm.
cons: Internal IT is traditionally been several years behind the times regarding the latest technology.  All around the company is good, and they know it, but that can come off as presumptuous.  Inter-departmental communication is fairly rare.  Because of their global outlook, they look for large global suppliers ... that's a bit of a bummer for small local suppliers.

job_title: Training Coordinator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Everyone here has been very helpful, pleasant and friendly. There is no stigma about asking questions and you will usually get a very detailed explanation, which is useful. Whether it has been on the products themselves or on tools and / or processes, I have had some tremendous help.
cons: Since I am a contractor, I was told I would be given a desktop computer. Seriously. And, I have, as many folks do, an analog phone. There is no IM or any communication tools outside of email and phone, which is analog. Very frustrating to someone who came from hi-tech. Since I am a contractor, and this position always will be, there is not a career path for me.

pros: none. Period  - if you value your career as a marketing manager stay as far away from this company as possible. Don't be persuaded by the potential salary or LTI. You're personal life will be horrific and the leadership will leave you questioning what made you even consider this an option in the first place. All managers who come say the same thing - 'this was a HUGE mistake'
cons:
1. Leadership is more political than congress and slower than the most infamous of any bureaucracy  
2. HR can not be trusted - with anything. I've literally seen HR lie to employees face, than turn around fire them in order to not be caught. 
3. Zero creative thinking within the organization and if you aim to be disruptive you will be met with folks who have mastered 'the game' and will use you to bolster themselves.

review_title: Poorly managed company with a bleak future
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Gym on site
Company shuts down over the holidays
cons: Lack of leadership and paralysis in management decision making has led to a total breakdown in employee morale.  Layoffs are expected on a quarterly basis leading to complete disengagement of employees. Most of the younger people are hoping for a severance package in the next round of layoffs and the older people are just hoping to hold out until their retirement kicks in.  Murky horizon for new R&D projects and declining sales in vascular products has squeezed out much of the talent in all divisions of the company.  Hierarchical structure of company coupled with highly politicized in-fighting between groups has eliminated project collaboration and restricted innovation.  The attitude throughout management is a complete lack of accountability for the direction of the company.

review_title: Great way to launch a career!
pros: Need to learn the business quickly to survive.  This forces you to engage with stakeholders and earn their respect.  Global presence with strong brand recognition.  Slow and steady wins the race.  Abbott is a legacy company with strong traditional values.  Integrity is excellent.  Trust Sr. Management to operate the business in prudent and pragmatic way.
cons: Always chasing quick dollars.  Afraid of taking calculated risk to get big rewards.  Incremental change and not transformational.  Communication from Sr. Management downward is often authoritative or non-existent.  Lack of innovation.  Focus instead on health care acquisition and M&A to survive.

review_title: Abbott Nutrition - a decent place to work
pros: You have a lot of freedom @ Abbott Nutrition.  It's your territory and you can run as you see fit.  However, with that responsibility comes accountability.  Your customers give you a lot of freedom as well.  Since you're sampling something they want (baby formula), and you're not required to get a physicians signature, you can pretty much come and go as you please.  No unnecessary waiting in the waiting room.

review_title: I had a wonderful time at Abbott Labs and would recommend it to many other people.

review_title: Too many managers /supervisors not enough actual workers.

Internal growth stifled among "lower-level" employees. Regardless of the employees level of experience - management prefers to bring in outside hires rather than promoting from within.

review_title: Qtr-to-Qtr Management waiting for the Next Big Thing

Sales blaming Marketing, Mktg blames R&D, R&D blames Manufacturing, Mnfg blames Quality Control, QC blames Management and Mgmt cuts costs to make divisional margin goal since 2011.
