Targets are never discussed with field team and more of it is quite stretched and unrealistic. There was a year the whole entire field team of the division couldn't hit their individual numbers. There are stories about people have been asked to keep quiet by paying them lump sums.

pros: If you want to settle down, this is a great company to work for where family always comes first.  Politics and bureaucracy exist like in all big companies. You just learn to go with the flow after fighting with these for sometime.  The Sr. Leadership does an amazing job in focussing divisional / departmental efforts in the things we do at Abbott.  I have seen most of the managers synch up with Company values relatively quickly and this helps individual contributors in many ways.  The company has great benefit package (company matching 401K, pension plan, yearly bonus, a decent medical/dental plan etc.,).
cons: If you are career driven performing an IT role, your career choices are; limited.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Good benefits, lots of different job opportunities for internal hire.  They're very good about giving people time off whenever needed, and probably the most flexible company I have worked for in terms of work/life balance.  The science at Abbott is cutting edge, and there is definitely a sense of company pride in the accomplishments of the R&D organization.
cons: Extremely poor communication from senior management.  Being a fantastic liar is a job qualification to become a corporate officer.  If management decides to sell a $9 billion division, having hundreds of people change all their benefit plans, sell houses, retire etc..... then decides to cancel it and tell them they are highly valued employees, they should not be surprised when people don't believe a word they are saying.

review_title: Like my job, but there is the "Big Company" bureaucracy to deal with.
job_title: Senior QA Professional in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Pension:  One of few companies left with a Pension
401k:  Abbott matches first 2% contributed with 5%
Work:  I enjoy my work in Quality and Tech Support
Co-workers:  For most part, smart and intelligent co-workers.
I enjoy being in a line of work that is going to help better society and healthcare.
cons:
Bureaucracy:  Things sometimes move slow, hindered by paperwork.
Promotion opportunities lacking:  Hard to move vertically in the organization.
At times told to "work harder" by management without giving any additional tools to accomplish this.
Unrealistic goals on projects that lead to rushed launches resulting in on-market products that could be better.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Abbott has the best CPS policy.  They have given the maximum 7% for the past several years.
cons: Management tends to stereotype people into the role that they start at the company with.  You find, especially in my department, more thought is given to bring outside candidates in then looking at the talent pool that is currently there.    I've seen our DVP's admin's be promoted faster than any other employee.  While other's in my group work towards higher education to end up in the same role with even more student loan debt/Tuition Assistance debt.  Its definitely a flawed system.

review_title: Great place to work. Progressive management philosophy, diverse work force at all levels.
job_title: R&D Engineer in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Energetic, fast placed culture. It is highly motivating to help improve people's vision in my own small way. Strong leadership team, although somewhat light in ophthalmic industry experience.
cons: Heavy workload.  Highly competitive external environment requires entire organization to rapidly adapt and be one step ahead of competition.  There's a tremendous amount of change under way, and while much of it is necessary given the environment, it could be paced and gated better.

review_title: Great company that values dedicated, smart, loyal employees.
pros:
Challenging work and great long term benefits (pension & RSU's)

Relatively good opportunities for promotion and cross divisional opportunities (although it's gotten less in the last 10 years as divisions have started to get more protective of their employees and prevented them from moving to other divisions)
cons:
As with many large, publicly owned companies there is always an expectation for immediate results that often distract leaders from looking down the road to anticipate the changing business landscape. 

It's become harder and harder in the last 10 years to find developmental opportunities for those with potential.

review_title: Great place to work with highly talented and dedicated people
pros:
There are opportunities here to do compelling work with extremely dedicated and talented people.      
I hit the ground running in the morning, and am highly engaged all day.
Unlike other places I have worked, I have almost never felt underutilized or bored.
Almost all employees I know are highly dedicated and are working at or near the top of their capacity.
In this busy environment, most are also helpful and good team players.
cons: In some departments, work life balance needs more consideration for best long-term performance of employees.

review_title: Be careful what you ask for.
pros: If your are in the right division or meet certain diversity attributes you have the potential to receive a wealth of training and experience.  You can also feel like you are have a positivie impact on your communities health.
cons: Pendulam has swung to far on diversity to the expense of good business decisions.  If you are in the wrong division (Diagnostics) look out, it's a cuthroat, selfish, environment focused on personal survival and playing the blame game.    The compliance related paperwork can smother any creativity, which you wouldn't get credit for anyway.

review_title: Still Chugging along - not much has changed
pros:
- Good pay and benefits
- A lot of responsibility
- Unless Miles sells your division you can probably work for many years there if you do a good job.
cons:
- Management is very cliquish, closed to change and behind the times - too many of them only care about sucking up to their boss and getting their next bonus check.
- Most upper management is very insular and arrogant - "if Abbott didn't invent it (which we don't invent too much anymore - we just buy it) it's not important."  Learning from outside sources, groups is almost discouraged.

pros: The company wants to grow market share by acquiring other established businesses and technologies. That diversity helps the company withstand economic downturns. The company has a good system for personal growth and carreer growth. You are encouraged (but not required) to move to new positions every several years so that you can learn more about the business.
cons: The company is very "political" and there is a strong emphasis on being "politically correct". That doesn't mean being liberal or conservative in your political views. It means the way you talk, the way you act, etc.

review_title: Great Company to Build Your Career
pros: Solid products that benefit patients, Great pay, Great training (continuous), Great benefits.  Ability to get promoted based on performance.  Rotations through Corporate Headquarters available.  Consistent good performance equals nice rewards!  As the marketplace continues to evolve, these jobs are becoming scarcer.
cons: To move from representative level into management, must rotate through Corporate Headquarters at some point, but many areas available in which to do this (operations, marketing, sales training, etc).  As in any company, some field managers are better than others.  The good news is , if you don't like your manager, sit tight and perform well, as they typically turn over fairly regularly.

review_title: If you go with the flow you can learn and grow.
job_title: Project Manager in North Chicago, IL
pros: There are many opportunities to move around if you want them. If you don't want to move around Abbott accepts that as well. Abbott's size is bot a good and a bad point -- as with every large company.  My division has some great data warehouse tools available.
cons: The IT support stinks, and the company is many times slow to communicate and act -- as most big companies are. If you let it Abbott will take over your life. Too many accountants creating unnecessary red tape. If we spent less time tracking money between departments we could eliminate half our accountants.

review_title: Unbalanced Compensation Practices Drain Talent From the Company
pros:
1) Large company that has a lot of lateral movement available
2) Online & classroom training programs that  were great for learning new marketable skills
cons:
1) If you are not management, you will not be properly evaluated and compensated
2) Company is not proactive about fixing problems.  Potential problems are ignored until they become nearly catastrophic.
3) The health benefits are very expensive and bare bones; especially for a company of this size.  I worked at small business with better health benefits that were cheaper.

review_title: Exhaustive administrative work, constant "development" that leads nowhere, and inefficient pod selling environment
pros:
1. Company Reputation
2. Benefits
3. Variety of jobs within the organization
cons:
1. "Big Brother" legal environment
2. Masses of salaried professionals justifying their jobs with meaningless, unproductive actions 
3. no ears to the ground, top-down management
4. management has created a culture of FEAR

review_title: Great place to work but in current state of flux
job_title: IT Project Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Global company providing many opportunities, whether job related, training, or community giving.  Great benefits and salary scales.
cons: Currently undergoing a reorganization which is leading to mass layoffs in all divisions.  This started in 2013 and is expected to continue for the next few years.  The intent is to have one platform and shared services.  Many Companies made this change ten years ago.  Yes, Abbott is behind the times.  Because of these changes and more of a focus on the international market, making numbers is being severely impacted.

pros: Pay and benefits commensurate to traditional American company with mediocre track record needing to attract good people to improve reputation
cons: Lots of politics, lack of internal alignment, lack of trust, confusing messages. Overall covered by a juvenile approach to leadership and key functions such as strategy, finance and marketing. Lack of respect also expressed through rude language and dismissive hierarchical behavior.  Can sense a certain desperation stemming from inability to grow the business and having to execute cuts instead, which have led to vicious cycle of finger pointing. Other Divisions and other companies look down  on this entity, not good for career, despite leadership insisting how "good this is" - Awareness issue?

pros:
- People are approachable and work well in teams. and the level of competitiveness is reasonable
- Company is expecting significant growth due the launch of a new product.
- Compensation is average/good and includes pension and equity
cons:
- Low tolerance for mistakes. I feel that some good people got burned or treated as scapegoats because of one-time failures but could have been given a second chance.
- Some favoritism. Management has a hard time disconnecting from mid-west corporate office culture.
- Despite the company growth opportunity, there are limited opportunities for personal growth in some of the HQ and Corporate functions

review_title: Not a great experience in general
job_title: Senior Field Service Engineer in Hong Kong
pros:
Work life Balance.
Flexible work hours.
Competitive Salary and benefit.
MNC, good for your portfolio
cons:
1. Goals and Objectives are all metrics that irrelevant to your daily activities.

2. Large gap between managers & front line service representative, they only care about numbers and don't really care what is happening in the field. Customer satisfaction is just a slogan. 

3. Very strict compliance. You work like a robot accordingly to manual or you risk your job. Creativity is not appreciated.

4. Everyone is your boss.  your line manager, dotted line managers, sales and external customers.

5. No Career development. (Or switch to sales)

6. Sales driven company.

7. Poor training. Minimal support. 

8. No backup. everyone call you even you are on leave.

9. No compensation for OT works.

10. Management change frequently in a short time. Old-school management style.

review_title: Great company and leadership with an eye for the future.
pros: Competitive pay and great benefits (3 weeks vacation to start, healthcare, 401k, profit sharing, and pension plan). Abbott is a company that once you start working, you can quickly see yourself being there a long time. Plenty of opportunities to move across divisions and nicely structured career path.
cons: Abbott has always been a silo-ed company. The ineffective communication between corporate functions and the divisions can cause major road blocks for projects. This may recede over time as there are major initiatives forcing cross-functional and divisional cooperation.

pros: The pay, particularly bonus and RSUs at the more senior levels.
cons: ADC has a horrible, bullying - even cruel - culture, where anyone who challenges authority, or is deemed to have contributed to an issue that prevents senior management from making bonus, is kicked out.  Years of loyal service can suddenly mean nothing. A spineless HR function does nothing to stop this. There's a clique of senior managers who look to take the credit for everything and blame for nothing. In addition, the work is relentlessly tedious, driven by fire drills from senior management, and often low value add, and job cuts, to drive profit, have increased the workload to the extent a sensible work life balance is impossible. There's very little career development other than on the job training. Other than this, a great place to work.

job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Abbott is a great company to work for, there are a lot of good, fun and hard-working employees.
cons: A few of the managers and directors are only still there due to their longevity with the company and not their ability to manage. This is due to how "buddy-buddy" they are with HR, their directors/superiors and anyone who oversees certain locations - and it's very obvious. All of this poorly reflects on the department but nothing is done about it - and in return, it only hurts the workers of said department.

review_title: The Train Is Off The Tracks
job_title: Information Technology in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Pay is good. Cafeteria is good.
cons: Core IT is a disaster. The old, tired women leading the BTS are overwhelmed and under qualified. They outsourced large portions of the business and have never had experience in this type of environment. They yell a lot but give little direction. Layoffs all the time (more today). No job is safe and hours are long. It's a total mess. Ask any one of the hundreds they've erased in the last 12 months.

pros: For management, there is good pay, good stock bonuses, good long-term incentives, good benefits, and a retirement pension plan (which most companies no longer offer).
cons:
There has been a lot of out-sourcing and layoffs, so definitely a "do more with less" environment. It is an increasingly difficult place to work. With the layoffs specifically, the work does not seem to go away, rather it gets piled onto the people who are retained. 
I find myself regularly asking if the pay and benefits worth it.

review_title: Time to think about the product.
pros:
Interesting work
Good feeling of helping people
401(k) plan is good
cons:
Senior Management do not seem to know what they are doing. If they weren't all good friends from years back they would have all fired each other by now. Almost all Senior Management came out of Allergan and those in other branches who developed successful businesses independently are psuhed out.
There are too many changes of plan.
Management take care of the details and don't seem to worry about the big picture.
A lot of good people have left and there is a gloomy feeling that things will continue to get worse. The stock price supports that.
There is WAY too much interest in business management bs and not enough focus on product and "gettn er done"

pros: The people that work in Abbott is very capable and inteligent, they are very supportive of your current goals as you maintain company goals also in your perspective.  Is a very team oriented enviorment everyone is willing to help and see how your project is a great experience to work for Abbott.
cons: There is very little compesation compare to the others companies in the same market.  Compesastions sometimes at lower levels are not the best for the type of work we are doing.  There are companies that are on the same market that recompensate better their employers and keep them interested in what the company has to offer.

pros: Benefits are better than most... salary, work/life
cons: Hieararchy atmosphere.... grade levels rule!  Very old school....too concious of grade levels instead of looking at what an individual can contribute.   Employees are actually told where they are allowed to park, based on their grade levels.      Directors/Managers  promote individuals that they know and then "follow the rules" and post the position, after they have told someone that they have gotten or will get the position.

review_title: Abbott is an amazing place to work- no regrets!
pros: Salary is competitive, opportunities for growth are solid, and I enjoy the people I work with. I feel like I have found a company that treats their employees very well and has an excellent work ethic, putting the customer and quality first.
cons: Budgets are always tight and we’re always looking to do more with less..., if you’re in medical devices you know this consistent across the industry- not just Abbott.  It’s frustrating when I don’t have the budget to really exercise rewards and recognition, while being asked to do more with less- forces you to get creative with morale boosting! Other than that, I have no complaints.

review_title: MBAs run running science is an experiment in futility
pros: A good place for starting out as a non Ph.D. scientist.  You learn the ins and outs of corporate life and the realities of dealing with the FDA.
cons: Rather low pay compared to the industry standard. WAY too much MBA nonsense to comply with that adds no value to you or the product.

review_title: Great benefits, dysfunctional culture at Abbott POC
job_title: Acute Care Specialist in Princeton, NJ
pros: As part fo the Abbott family, you have the advantages of all of the medical and other benefits the company offers.  Yearly increases,  great performance bonus opportunities.
cons: Culture is dysfunctional.  Your success if not just your performance, but who you are best buddies with.  People get promoted and are given opportunities that are based upon who your friend is.  Poor work life balance.  As one VP noted, "I don't care which 12 hours out of 24hours  I get, as long as I get my 12 hours from you". APOC comes first.

review_title: Revolving door for frontline leaders (production supervisors)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Casa Grande, AZ
pros: Competitive Salary, Good Benefits, Good People
cons: It's a revolving door for frontline leaders (production supervisors).  Middle management throw you in the fire without giving you the tools to become successful.   Upper management is not holding each other accountable because there's a good ole boy mentality.  There's a lack of work life balance when working the condensed work week (12 hour shift) due to supervisors having to complete investigations and training.   In addition, Supervisors are required to work holiday's without any compensation or a thank you.

review_title: Used to be a great company, if you are non-exempt, you don't matter
job_title: Field Service Engineer in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Stable employment, ok benefits, ok holidays.
cons: Salaries are nearly frozen, no bonuses or retirement plan if hired after a certain date, however managers get all the perks the non-exempt staff does not. Ridiculously low raises (1-2% if one gets it at all), low starting pay compared to even other divisions of Abbott; emphasis is on production and not on patient safety during installations and frantic scheduling,  low moral hence the need for "team building".

review_title: Ehh, ok place to work, but it feels like every other corporate pharma...
pros: One of the best reasons to work at Abbott would be that everyone really did know everyone's name and most managers were understanding about needing to take time off on short notice.
cons: One less satisfying reasons to work at Abbott was that it was hard to be fully appreciated for what you did.  They expected you to go above and beyond, but they had the nerve to give you an "average" - not great or even good - review to justify them NOT giving you a raise.

review_title: Start your career here, then leave!
pros:
Good benefits (hope they keep the pension for the older generation) 
Some opportunities for promotion if you smooze with the bosses
cons:
Not a professional workplace, too much gossip, hiding information, etc.
Not clear enough expectations, or they constantly change their minds on the "#1 priority'
Always an "emergency" from your bosses
Not enough recognition for hard work, reward politics and especially if you fit their 'diversity quota'.....   there is such a thing such as reverse discrimination.....   and yes they do set and have a quota for 'diversity'

pros: If you have proper management that supports your work and decisions, then you will be okay. The work is there and there never seems to be an end of things to do. You will learn new talents and skills.
cons: Work is there but, at times it seems that other aspects of the company do not communicate well so projects get cancelled or delayed. It makes you feel like you're just wasting your time with meaningless work.

pros:
- Great peers cross-functionally who are more than willing to help and collaborate
- Extremely capable and smart people across the board
- Benefits are good (Medical, PTO, 401k)
cons:
Very top heavy - There are more people managing work than people actually doing the work.

Expected long hours, low compensation, low morale, no encouragement from management. 

Regulatory Affairs has had a 40% turnover rate - people are unhappy but management continues to turn a blind eye to the fact. There is always more work to be done, expectations to meet and a continued lack of appreciation for accomplishments.

Good luck getting promoted - what's the point anyways when everyone continues to leave? 

In all honesty, there are better options out there in the Bay Area. Explore them.

review_title: No direction, managers have lost the plot.
pros: Good pension, but you will be stressed out and dead before you can draw it. There were lots of pros when first joining. But they soon stop them once you are tied in
cons:
No mentoring. Managers & Directors use bullyboy tactics. No career progression. Work evenings for free. Management have no idea how to walk the floor. 
UK NHS is a shambles behind the curtain. God help us.

review_title: Contractor Beware, but the sky's the limit for Executives
pros: Great pay, quality-oriented, genuine concern of employee welfare, future roadmap has been drawn and steps are being taken to follow that roadmap, management is cognizant of short-comings and are trying to address them
cons: Very poor use of technology, one system serving one need, need to create cross-functional integration of systems and services, hiring freeze in place for contractors waiting on release of new product is not a good business model, management loses workers with valuable information because of Senior Management practices, company falls short of intended roadmap, there's a huge gap between corporate roadmap and actual implementation

job_title: Marketing Manager in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Results oriented, focus on business, make decisions, team work, leadership, honest, committed, analytic, creative, responsible, persuasive, reliable, dedicated, confident, rigth thinking, solutions generator, open mind, organized, sociable, conciliator, generous, field work,
cons: impulsive, passionate, proud, strict, direct in speaking, hot temper, men of few words, workaholic, I prefer to work in a team, dislike lies and gossips. routine death me, I can´t hide my disagree, mistrusted, I need to participate in field work, I can´t stay long time in work officce, no expert in excel and digital media, my tone of voice is soft then, some times people don´t listen me correctly.

review_title: Great culture created by the strong leadership.
pros: From the CEO on down, you have great people working hard to make life better for all.   An organization that recognizes that people are one of the greatest assets a company has and the opportunity to stretch oneself is available if you choose to be accountable for your own personal development.
cons: Like most large organizations change is slow to happen and there are many layers of bureaucracy to contend with.  Abbott culture has been cultivated from a pharma perspective and there are growing pains in understanding that the medical device world is different.

review_title: It's all about VPs and above making their money.
pros: Great coworkers.  Nice environment.
cons: Cannot recommend the logistics vp at all.  Terrible human.  Selfish and greedy, only out for himself with no respect for the team   Company is not nimble.  Outsourced IT, benefits, payables, receivables, and for awhile, customer service.  This sends the message that your customers aren't important enough to maintain a relationship, and the data needed to drive decision making should be owned by an outsider.  How can teams be proactive if they can't get data?  How can they think ahead if management just cares about their bonus?

job_title: Senior Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: Abbott is a large company with lots of resources.  Working in biotech you really feel like you are helping people live better lives on a daily basis.  401K matching program and health benefits were good, and vacation time was also generous.
cons: Abbott's medical device business tends to acquire a lot of companies.  Integration with new companies can be a big issue.  Large company is less generous with stock options, and the stock price doesn't move very much, so the stock options can only be considered a nice little "bonus" to the annual salary.  Pay seemed to lag behind other medical device companies in the area.

pros: Great big company with resources, pay well and have great benefits. In general morale is good. Great location by the bay if you live in the east bay. I used to work for a startup organization, and I find the quality of work and enviornment much more stimulating here, with a much better work life balance.
cons: communication between department, groups not great. Too much going on with lack of focus. Sometimes the managemnt strategy does not make sense. They recently had a management change, which may or may not affect which direction they go. The offices are not that great, but renovations are planned.

review_title: Great Company Worldwide, Bad management practice in Kuwait
pros: Well Established company Worldwide, with good products and services.  Fortune 500 and world renowned
cons: Management ( Country + Regional) Extermely improfessional, no management skills, no people skills. HR for namesake(doesnt practicall exist). OEC is only on paper, but the management finds ways to bypass and cheat the system. Forced resignations, terminations of good employees. Alot of Racism, lack of growth due to racism!

pros: Decent restaurants and shopping close by, Old Town Temecula is close enough to visit during a lunch break. That's about it.
cons: Management totally sucks. The biggest bunch of witless worms led by an unethical slug and his progeny that consist mainly of ineffective paranoid brown-nosers. Rats, (as in rodents), frequently are spotted in the administrative buildings and are addressed without any sense of urgency. As are gas leaks. With frequent and regular large layoffs, morale is low and any good people that remain are in the process of jumping ship. Abbott picked up a perfectly good, functioning company, implanted their management and drove it into the ground. As there is no longer any R&D, there is no future. Don't bank on picking up new companies to save them as they aren't any good at integrating them into the quality system.

review_title: Abbott is a comfortable place to work but slow to change
pros:
At Abbott, there are lots of opportunities and it easy to move between areas if you are willing to network.
The benefits are good (healthcare, 401k, on-site fitness center, Clara Abbott organization offers classes such as financial management).
It is easy to achieve a good work-life balance.
cons:
Abbott loses many good people because it does not provide opportunities and salary for those that deserve it.
The company is slow to change.
There are significant culture and resource differences depending on the group you work for.

review_title: A patient-focused company in need of strategic direction
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at ADC are:  job security, opportunity for advancement, compensation and benefits, and the chance to work in an industry where your work directly impacts quality of life for diabetic patients.  At ADC, employees understand the importance of their work.
cons: Location in Alameda, CA is not ideal.  Campus is drab and uninspiring.  Organization tends to work in silos and not collaborate well across functional areas. While this is not atypical of large companies, poor collaboration and communication are major challenges for this company.  Senior management should take steps to address these challenges in the company culture.

job_title: Reliability Engineer in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Most people are sort of nice
cons: Extremely sexist environment; low pay for the area; too many politics halt productivity and stifle innovation

review_title: A great company for a career, or several careers
pros: Abbott has a strong philosophy of work-life balance that shows in both policy and practice.  There is also a strong culture of promotion from within, and with such a large and diverse company, there are always new career paths to pursue.
cons: Abbott has a somewhat "plodding" mentality where change does not come quickly or easily.  The high rate of internal promotion tends to limit the amount of new ideas introduced from people with experience in other companies or industries.

job_title: Material Review Coordinator in Irving, TX
pros: Competitive salary and great benefits combined with a caring attitude. The atmosphere appears to be one of promise and that you are a part of something great. That what this company does matters.
cons: After all is said and done, employees just become a number when it comes to whether the company is competitive on a global scale. An American company that would outsource American jobs in a minute if it means being more profittable.

review_title: Great benefits.  Paternalistic culture.  Couldn't change career path.
job_title: HR Manager in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Total compensation was excellent, especially when you factor in retirement benefits.  My 401K, after two years of working at Abbott, was better off than expected and in comparison to friends.  I had good opportunities to work "above my pay grade" so long as I demonstrated exceptional performance.  Got to work in Europe for a year and that experience was very well executed.
cons: I wanted to move from one function to another and despite networking and getting interviews and an offer, I was asked to stay in my current function.  This was not aligned with my career interests.

pros:
great salary
great benefits
nice amenities
work/life balance
cons:
work/life balance though states to be company initiated - is at managers discretion -
Promotions without red tape

review_title: Too many chiefs not enough indians
pros: good compensation and benefits.  Many great people working at lower level positions, sales, admins, IT
cons:
Upper management was very unclear in focus and direction. Mid management was terrible with communication
Tons of favoritism.   Goals were NEVER delivered in a timely manner to make an impact on them. Never truly set up for success. Too many EGOS among managers in house and in the field. More marketing staff than was necessary and most were not effective. Leadership was inconsistent.

pros:
- I had the best colleagues of my life at Abbott Molecular.  The culture is phenomenal.  Everyone does everything they can to see projects be successful, even if its not their project.  People seem to genuinely like each other.  I know that I genuinely liked all of my colleagues.  The term "best and the brightest" applies.  
- The entire place is highly educated.  Even the warehouse guys have degrees.  
- Lower-middle managers are excellent.  They work hard to be supportive to their people, and work hard to be supportive of the company.  It was incredibly easy to be supportive of my manager and to try and make them look good, because the managers make sure to give credit where credit is due, and ultimately they have the best interests of the company in their mind, not petty personal stuff. 
- this depends on the individual manager and the individual situation but generally managers work with employees to have flexible schedules for people with kids, people who need to go to the doctor, etc.  Work from home, provided it is not abused, is usually on the table.
- Pay was about what it should be.
- Very ethical company.  Management is always looking to do the right thing.  Every day I left work, I felt that we were doing the right thing.
- Quality is important.  Every action has multiple controls and checks to make sure that mistakes are not made.
- Safety is important.  Management actively takes steps to make sure that people are behaving in a safe manner.  When they say safety is number 1, they mean it.
- If there is anything that happens by mistake, management generally does not blame / scapegoat the individuals, but instead looks for ways to prevent he same issues from recurring.
-
cons:
- Upper management.  Upper management is on a rotation here.  People are always on their toes to try and meet the next demand by sr management for fear that they will be next on the layoff list if they dont.

-  layoffs.  There is a culture at AM of people waiting for the shoe to drop.  Might be PTSD from other divisions.  the constant state of fear of being the next to be laid off starts to mess with your brain after awhile.  And yes, if you are generally disliked, they will "lay you off".  Doesn't matter if you are right.  If you are seen as being a pain in the butt, next time they have a layoff you should expect to be on the list.

-Attrition model.  It is practically impossible to move up in this division.  Most of the people have been in the same job function for 10+ years.  This is partially due to the gridlock, in that nobody moves up.  Whenever someone leaves, they either don't replace the headcount at all, or the replacement takes so long, they may as well have not replaced the headcount at all.  Additionally, saw it happen multiple times where the hiring manager preferred to reach out to other divisions / other departments rather than moving people up.

- Contract employment.  I am grateful for my experience at AM.  I would have loved to have stayed with the company.  Would have even taken a pay CUT if it meant I could stop the contingent worker cycle of pain, where every six months your contract needs to be actively extended or you are gone.  Even if you are well regarded and can get continuous extensions, once you hit two years by their agreement with Tapfin, your employment contract gets severed, and you cannot be re-employed as a contract worker for 30 days.  I knew several people who went through this process more than once.  And it was heartbreaking.

- Morale.  When I left I had a cadre of people be genuinely happy for me, and even more mention their jealousy in wanting to get out too.

- PhD or bust.  If you don't have a doctorate of one kind or another, whether PhD, Pharm D, MD, JD, your advancement is even more limited.

pros:

cons:
Relocation to other countries receive a one-time relocation bonus to cover 2-3 months of settling down. Salaries are readjusted to the local currency, so one might actually lose salary depending on exchange rates.

Abbott has been playing corporate chess, buying and selling large companies creating a snowball effect of day to day operations. As a consequence, employees have ridiculous hours (50-60+ /week at least 2/3 of the time) due to major transformations, lack of proper processes and not enough staff.

On top of this, lots of outsourcing happened in the last 3 years. More than 2/3 of local back-office and 1/3 commercial employees were fired (displaced is the jargon used) and replaced with cheaper workers in India & Philipines. Due to this, morale is low and although older employees are approachable and helpful they are also tired and demotivated or just simply passive.

This situation will continue in 2017 as Abbott just bought ST Jude, a very large healthcare company with large presence in Australia and many countries.

Career path is not clear and one can stay in the same job on the same salary for many years with no more than CPI readjustments. (allowances are not CPI readjusted).

Senior management plays communication by the Corporate book which is very USA oriented and not culturally adequate for Australia. Most employees don't believe on what upper management says.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL

cons: Abbott Molecular started off with great potential but I believe missed it's window of opportunity to be great. Peter Principal is rampant at both Abbott Molecular and Abbott Diagnostics and will be very difficult to change.  Innovation comes only through projects that are easy and drop in their laps while those that take risks and are innovative are often left to hang on their own with little support. pros:

There's no accountability for management. No management reviews, no exit interviews. There's no place to express your needs/concerns without having to open a full-blown complaint with HR, and people are too scared of the consequences to open the complaint because of managers' passive aggressive reactions to feedback.
Managers pretend to have your career growth in mind and lead you on (breadcrumbing) with vague "growth opportunities".  In a few cases, a singular opportunity was offered to multiple people during respective 1:1s. When questioned about timelines, managers continue to avoid giving a direct answer (i.e. "soon"). You're told "you're doing everything you could be doing and more", leaving you helpless and in limbo indefinitely. Managers will claim that the situation is beyond their control (which very well may be true) but you expect your boss to go to bat for you regardless of the situation.
Compensation is also grossly inequitable, as management will hire someone with an accomplished resume at a considerably higher rate, rather than promoting/give a raise to a veteran employee who has worked 12 hour days for 5+ years and has exhibited mastery of the role. Managers continue to ignore the disparity as the workflow suffers from demotivated employees and inexperienced new hires. 
New hire training also falls on coworkers rather than management. The unofficial trainer is volun-told to create the training material without a change in their job description, and is still expected to complete their own work.
If you plan on taking any PTO, you're expected to complete your vacation-length's amount of work before leaving, effectively defeating the purpose of vacation.

job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Chicago, IL

cons: Relationships matter, sometimes more than one's actual output of work.  This is not always a bad thing but there are some individuals that were being promoted that had no business other than who they were close with.

pros: There are none in my opinion.
cons: RUN RUN RUN far away from this company.  If you are going to this job thinking it will be better than your last IT WON'T BE.  Move on.  The management staff is incompetent. The place is a good ol' boys club.  I've never seen so many men be so dismissive of the women and treat them like they are their personal secretaries. pros:

- Great environment to learn a lot about the healthcare industry.

review_title: Abbott Labs is a great company with a stable future.
job_title: Senior Network Analyst in Phoenix, AZ

cons: It is a large company and sometimes it seems they are in the position of following the industry instead of leading. review_title: Could (and should) be a great place to work.
job_title: Project Manager in Abbott Park, IL
pros: It is a company founded on caring for people and trying to make their lives better through health care.
cons: There are two strata within the company.  1) Those who are below mid-management who are expected (and usually do) produce measurable results which contribute to the bottom line.  2) Mid-management and above who spend 99% of their time playing political power games and contributing nothing to the company (and at the same time making the work of the first group harder).

review_title: Lots of hard work and lots of red tape while being kept in the dark of the future direction
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Salary compensation was very good, but there was very limited potential for upside for a job well done. Prefer more merit based compensation for objectives being met to encourage staff to do the right things for the business to move it forward.
cons: Upper management had another agenda; many second guessed your actions and abilities without ever giving opportunity to succeed and shine.

review_title: This is a place to build your career... Not just a job.
job_title: Regional Sales Analyst in Columbus, OH
pros: Management does not want to see you fail. There is a supportive network of employees/friends who will encourage you to do your best and strive for success.
cons: Very strict start times and lunch hours with very little flexability unless you've worked at the company for 15+ years.

review_title: One of the best companies to work for!
pros:
Many opportunities for growth and continuing education.
Outstanding benefits and bonuses.
Excellent leadership and management.

Under some circumstances, it can be difficult to get promoted.
Management directives to assign low performance scores to at least a certain minimum % people in a group for performance reviews. job_title: Pediatric Sales Representative in Washington, DC

Opportunities to learn other functions (depending on your willingness to go above and beyond).
I would recommend working here to gain valuable experience on how to handle difficult situations.
cons:
Compensation for the bay area is on the lower side.
Departments are very silo.
Company culture needs to be revitalized, specifically in terms of accountability and rewards/recognition.

pros:

- some great managers and fellow employees
- part of Abbott, so options elsewhere

review_title: Not a "Golden Child" and young - Go Somewhere Else
pros:
Still has a great retirement package if they allow you stay (401K  & Pension)
College Tuition;

Annual raise is based on events out of control and if you're a worker, you're screwed; manager's aren't affected.

review_title: Important work, great way to learn cardiac devices
pros: This job has some very good aspects to it, you learn how to deal with and explain concepts to every skill level from novices to experts, you gain huge amounts of experience with cardiac devices and will have developed expertise in this area quickly.
cons: The workload can be excessive in times where product issues or fda recalls are announced.  This has improved since I left the position.  Few people see this as a tangible career outside of management so good people come and go frequently.  The pay isn't that great.

review_title: A solid place to work for
pros: Working in the Bay Area is great.  Comfortable 9-5 job.  Also get great perks including ordering EAS products as well as pedisure and similac.  The benefits for employees is great and Abbott is a very stable company since it is in so many different areas of health care.
cons: Sometimes projects can be very slow and take awhile to complete.  The surrounding area of Abbott is not the safest place to be.  Abbott needs more engineers so that projects can work faster and so there is more manpower to finish projects.

review_title: Abbott Vascular is a Great Place to work.
pros: Abbott Vascular has many programs to help individuals to advance their carreers. In addition the company has programs to help improve your health and finances. The company values people who are inovative and promote constant changes such as Six Sigma and Lean concepts.
cons: For a non-professional candidate the only way to go to work at Abbott Vascular is to start as a temporary employee and after a year you can be hired on as a permanent employee.

review_title: They are cautious about improvements to business and process.
pros: Many smart people, well-respected products for hospitals and labs. Interesting jobs working to help people medically with products and services.  Some management is good - if you are lucky you get good support.
cons: Shrinking US presence, much of production moved overseas and US people just laid off. As mentioned above, quality of management is hit or miss, with more on the miss side.

review_title: Good place to work, to have a career.

review_title: Good parent company, but Nutrition division needs a lot of help.

Old-school style managers 
LOTS of politics

Little flexibility in hours and working from home
Culture often requires you to work nights and weekends to complete projects. Lots of 'firedrills' 
CEO is great but management at Nutrition headquarters is subpar.

review_title: Worked into the Ground - No Appreciation
pros: Good benefits, job tasks were rewarding
cons: Worked on an average of 70 hrs per week. Management's attitude is that this is expected. When I quit I was handed a check - that was it. No  exit interview or explanation that my benefits would be cut off once I walked out the door. Upper management is rude and condescending. Never appreciated, told that we will not receive any parties or anything for Christmas. No company picnic for years, no pats on the back.

job_title: Quality Control Technician in San Diego, CA

pros: They have great benefits including 401K, profit sharing and pension.  The health insurance is pretty good as well.  They do try to keep any extra time to a minimum.

There are some situations where people move to other departments or other divisions which helps. review_title: Decent company, management needs to keep younger talent

review_title: Nice building, shame about the culture

Guaranteed end of year bonus 
Good pension
Work/life balance OK

Cliquey.  Mid-level promotions due to personality/network rather than hardwork & expertise.

Difficult to get things changed even if systems are outdated and inefficient - I was often told "we've always done it this way" when offering solutions.  Guaranteed bonus meaning hard work not rewarded.  Salary poor in comparsion with other similar jobs.

review_title: Strong performing company, competitive salary and benefits, smart people, bureaucratic.

New managers who micromanage contributed to a culture of mistrust in the sales force. Many veteran reps have left due to inexperienced managers and culture shift within the company.

job_title: Financial Analyst in Abbott Park, IL

pros: Friendly people to work with. Was taken on 4 trips away during my year there, good fun. The company spends a lot of money on meeting away like Spain or Europe - got to stay in nice hotels and have nice dinners. Everyone got to get there hair down and really got to socialise together.
cons: Quite dull office environment. Low pay for placement students. I found the office location very remote and there is no much going on out there. Very small choice of places to go during lunch etc. Also quite a small number of people working in the office.

review_title: Decent place to work, but senior managment needs improvement

Get to interact with people from International divisions, which really gives a global perspective of your job

Products considered second tier to competitors'.

review_title: No growth opportunities in a post-merger environment
job_title: Senior Contract and Business Analyst in Austin, TX

State-of-the-Art training facilities for both Employees and Customers.

For more seasoned Employees it seems as though the hiring profile has shifted to a more STEM background.

Training can be hyper-focused at a STEM level so could be a challenge to develop as quickly as others if you lack this background.

review_title: Hollow Shell of Former Guidant's Vascular Interventions
pros:
The benefits are above standard
Best sales force in the medical device business & they know how to launch a product

review_title: A company who treats employees like gold!

cons: No clear direction other than cost-cutting, and overburdening remaining employees. Indiscriminate cuts take away important job functions and knowledge base. Sometimes there are conflicting projects and lots of stress.

review_title: Great for experience, but not someplace you can be happy
pros: The benefits were solid, the people are good and the products are generally of high quality.  It is a great place to gain experience in the industry and it looks great on a resume when seeking your next opportunity.
cons: Where to start?  There is little to no growth opportunity within the Division.  The division has not been replacing employees who have left which has resulted in people taking on many extra duties with no recognition.  In one functional area, the department has last 14 employees in the past 6 months with no new hires and no plan to replace the personnel who left.  Attrition is huge within the past year.  Most people try to do a good job, but the bureaucratic hurdles are sometimes so challenging and cumbersome that it wears people down.  There is a large level of middle management without enough workers to get things accomplished and Executive Management is too far removed from the daily operations to understand what is going on.  The morale is horrible and people will continue to leave if things do not start changing.  There is huge favoritism that goes on within the entire organization.  Management manages to meet numbers to look good, rather than making the hard decisions that need to be made.  No-one wants to cause any commotion and raise the issues to management.

pros: Abbott has great benefits, very competitive salary and bonus plan. Plenty of opportunity to move within the organization if you are willing to relocate.
cons: Some of the older management is very mid-western; corporate is in Chicago and they seem to have a hard time changing to adapt to the West Coast way of managing. Behind the times in that aspect. Not good about work life balance.

review_title: What went wrong at Abbott Vascular?
pros: Abbott does treat its long term employees with some respect. However, contractors are gone as soon as the next wave of layoffs is announced.
cons:
They took a gem of a company called Guidant and performed a Purge on the 4000 employees.
All that was left when the dust settled was the remnants of a great company to work for. Guidant gave bonuses sometimes to the tune of 50% of the employees base salary. Abbott Vascular is nothing like the once proud company-Guidant.

job_title: Finance Manager in Abbott Park, IL

pros: Great Benefits: good medical/dental & 401k contribution

review_title: Abbott is a great group of highly dedicated to meeting the needs of patients around the world
job_title: Marketing Director in North Chicago, IL

pros: Worked with very smart and very motivated people. Everyone was really invested in the projects and devoted to putting the time in to do things right. Company has great professional development training, financial workshops, and tuition assistance available. Definitely had a feeling that there was an emphasis on quality and safety.
cons: Felt as if there was increasing interest in acquiring R&D from startups, and consequently, less of a focus on internal R&D. Could sense sometimes tension between different levels of management.

pros: Amazing technology, unlimited things to learn as the product is very complex. Nice people to work with. Great for young people to start off, can gain lots of experience with different aspects of the business. Competitive compensation and benefits.
cons: Long work hours with potential no pay over time. If you don’t deliver, you get zero for effort and trying. Sometimes not deliver could mean that senior management team or quality or regulatory do not agree with the proposal. Lots of favoritism.

pros: Very friendly work environment; everyone is willing to help and assist in any way possible. cons: The Abbott Diabetes Care division of Abbott Labs is still reasonably small. It's also relatively new, making the environment very start-up oriented. There are not too many downsides, although pay could possibly be higher. Also, conflicts with QA/QC regulations may occur, depending on what department you may be working in.

review_title: quality company in health care - hopefully the expected reorg went over well

review_title: Overall was positive until the last two years which were difficult,  then got laid off.

pros:

the best you can find in a  multicultural company is the people working there.

job_title: Senior Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Since the company is well established, it has proper design control and development procedures in place.  This is useful to learn, but requires seeking of guidance to understand its value, as little of its importance is explained to you on the job.  Many of my colleagues here are incredibly intelligent and competent people, who provide me with insight and guidance.  However, most people would admit that they are unhappy here, which make for a less than ideal environment to persist in.  Learn what you can from this experience to place yourself in a better place.  Benefits (health insurance, company perks, profit-sharing, 401K match) are generous.
cons: Upper management has a tendency to micromanage and not trust its personnel, despite hiring top talent.  Decisions are made and ordered down to scientists with little rationale or explanation.  Leadership seems chaotic.  Some managers are also promoted to levels beyond their capabilities, whereas competent personnel are mistreated and micromanaged, indicating a lack of meritocracy.  There is very little room for career growth, as the higher management positions are saturated with some doing just enough to get by and waiting to collect their pensions.  Scientists partake in technician-level tasks that require little-to-no intellectual effort.  Very little innovation is integrated into the products developed here.  Ideas and methodologies are stale.  Roles here are very siloed, thus resulting in limited exposure to the development process as a whole.  Job is not time-demanding, but due to sporadic decision-making from upper management, it may require last minute and weekend cramming to meet deadlines.  While this may not be pervasive throughout, there is some culture here where people/groups function "just enough to get the job done," such that when issues arise, it gets dumped on other groups.  Be prepared that R&D receives little acknowledgment and credit for their efforts in bringing products to fruition, as well as trouble-shooting on-market issues--customer-facing groups (sales & marketing) often jump to take and get credit, hence the lack of meritocracy.

review_title: Used to be great place to work at
pros:
Abbott still has a very good benefits package, including pension plan, profit sharing bonus, cheap (to the employee) health care plans, minimum of 3 weeks vacation going up to 6 weeks depending on years of service.
If work load permits, to take unpaid time off in addition to vacation is not a problem.
Interesting work
cons:
Generally the company seems to go from a good place to work at towards a so-so or even bad place to work at.
Decisions and policies made by upper management (quality director or vice president?) and implemented at the start of 2010 which had a huge impact on morale from people I spoke with, included that non-exempt employees have to use punch clocks, after years of being able to fill in time card on the computer. This, with no apparent abuse of previous system, made us feel like we're not trust worthy. Added to that was implementation of point system for taking sick days and not being on time: Whenever someone had to take a sick day and didn't give at least 24 hours prior notice, one point was added to your account (like you know 24 hours in advance if you're gonna get sick). If you were sick this week and then the following Monday you were still sick, a second point would be added. If you were late more then 15 min (5 min for production workers), half a point would be added.
There were some more things that would add points, which I don't remember anymore.
After getting 4 points, a scolding meeting was to be had with the manager. If more then 6 points were accrued in 6 months, a permanent mark in your personal file, etc., up to suspension or termination.
Non-exempt employees not allowed to do ANY overtime (even 8.1 hours/day instead of 8.0 more then once every 2 weeks, resulted in a stern talking to...) while exempt employees had to take up the slack (like working 10 -12 hours) since they were not getting paid by the hour.
Impossible to achieve goals added to the goals that were determining the yearly bonus (in an apparent drive to lower bonus payouts)
Laying off full time employees while at the same time hiring contract people.
There are several more policies that were implemented this year that severely restricted or eliminated work place flexibilities that we had since I started working there.
Maybe it doesn't sound bad if you never had those things, but to change them with no reason other then some director or VP had the genius idea that it will work better with this or that changed, just sucks.

job_title: Section Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Abbott Labs has above average benefits including medical, dental, vision, and flex spending.  They offer a pension plan and 401(k) retirement plan plus company matching with no vesting period.  From the 1st day of employment, all vacation days (prorated, up to 3 weeks) for that year will be given, instead of having to slowly accrue them.  Additional to the compensation are the annual profit sharing and an incentive plan for the technical/upper level folks.  Stock options are given for upper level folks.  If relocation is required for a current employee, the relocation department takes care of all aspects of the move.  There is a corporate tuition reimbursement program for relevant coursework leading to a degree/certificate, provided that a minimum grade is achieved.  Most departments have enough money in the budge to send employees to various training classes.  With many divisions, it is easy to transfer across departments and gain a wide array of knowledge across its many businesses.
cons: From my experience, managers were more interested in project goals and deadlines than the career development of their subordinates.  Inspirational and sharp general managers are rare.  Each division and site operate as its own company, so the company culture can be varied throughout.  Typical salary is only average, and annual merit increases average 2-3%.  Those percentages are set by corporate and sometimes may not take into account the typical merit increase of the local market.  If hired at the low end of the pay scale, it is difficult to justify a raise to be equitably paid compared to others within the company.

review_title: Challenging work. Moving forward, yet stifled by its own quality bureaucracy that adds unnecessary expense and time.
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Reasonable pay.   Low pay to start, but after 15-20 years here, you will be compensated competitively.

The work-life balance is good in some business segments.  If you are in a division that has double-digit sales growth, the pressure is normal workplace pressure, and therefore the work-life balance is good.  If you move to a division that is not meeting its numbers, expect low morale, and long hours to make up for this.

Abbott is a solid company, that has endured increasing business pressure for decades, and thrives by adapting to the changing business climate.   Executive management do an outstanding job to move the company forward.    They take into account all stakeholders  (shareholders first, but keep employees in mind too).   I respect the strategic moves the company takes.

Company claims to encourage employee development, and I strongly believe that they are trying.   There are some initiatives in place to foster change.  However, Abbott can be its own worst enemy, in that it gets in the way of itself, with quality system that delays ideas and adds unnecessary costs to health care.
cons:
Benefits are solid, except for health care benefits.    Abbott's health plan choices are surprisingly poor.    For a health care company, I was surprised to find how poor our choices were, and how little coverage Abbott provides.    The health plans do provide great routine and preventative care.  However, if you experience even minor non-routine medical needs, be prepared to pay a lot out of pocket.   

If you are job seeker, and contemplating a job offer from Abbott, I would highly recommend doing through research into the health plans, health network (not very many choices), the weekly payroll deductions, and the out-of-pocket charges you will incur for health coverage before taking the job.   While health insurance should be one of many factors in considering a job, I advise you to concentrate on this benefit with Abbott.   I have been pleased with all the other Abbott benefits, but I am still surprised how little Abbott provides, when compared to other companies, across many industries.    I've been pleased with my career here, but due to Abbott's poor health plan, poor network, and significant expenses due to the low coverage on the plans - I have began a job search.  I find that I can no longer work for a company that provides cut-rate health insurance, with few options for its employees.

The quality management system at Abbott is crushing to development, innovation, and timely execution.   Of course, everyone expects high quality products, every time - and I believe this is a must.   However, the way Abbott has set up its quality system adds unnecessary time to every step of development.   Be prepared to take 1 step forward, and 2 steps back when trying to come up with improvement.   When trying to get approval, quality managers will simply say "No", without providing a "why" or provide feedback on how or where to improve.   The quality system here seems to feed on itself, simply creating more jobs, more bureaucracy, more expense - but not improving the process in any manner.   Be prepared to expect long delays, very slow changes, and lots of resistance to innovation and improvement.

job_title: Clinical Research Scientist in Montreal, QC
pros:
Overall company: Company has good benefits (medical, dental, vision, etc.) and decent long-term incentives (pension, RSUs above a certain employee grade, etc.). As a division of Abbott Laboratories, AV is a very stable company (i.e. not a risky start-up that might go under).
Clinical Science department: There are a number of good, committed clinical research scientists who work very hard, know what they are doing, and are committed to the end goal of bringing new treatment options to patients. Cross-functionally there are also a lot of very good people to work with.
cons:
Overall company: AV sometimes is a little out of sync with the parent Abbott Laboratories company. People at AV are held at lower pay grades than at the parent Abbott company, even though the cost of living is higher. Consistent "doom and gloom" message from senior management to encourage belt-tightening measures over the past 2 years have significantly lowered overall morale. Excessive red tape procedures and processes, even for a large company.
Clinical Science department: Weak leadership with poor management skills at multiple levels. Senior management insulates themselves with too many layers of middle management. Extremely limited opportunities for advancement, since department is very reluctant to promote even though promotions seem to happen in other departments. In the past couple of years about half of the clinical science department have left AV for other companies (including some of the best people) but senior mgmt has not allowed backfill so the workload for the remaining employees has gotten worse to the point that things don't get done or get done at much poorer quality because there just aren't enough people to do all the work at high quality.

review_title: Working at Abbott has been one of the most rewarding and educational experiences I have ever had, to date
pros:
- The best development programs (MDP/PDP) right out of college have to be at Abbott. You will be challenged and have to work in a different functional area that's outside your comfort zone, but that's a good thing. That's how you learn and grow!
- The people are all wonderful to work with, and if you get the get the chance to work as a PDP/MDP, you will learn so much more about the various divisions, you will get incredible opportunities to network and you'll really learn what you like (and don't like).
- The benefits are nice; decent 401(k) contribution, profit sharing and a pension is offered for up to 35 years of service. You can also get free Abbott (or AbbVie) drugs too, if you are prescribed them by your doctor.
cons:
- Abbott has a fair amount of sites in the Bay Area and the cost of living adjustment that is offered can honestly be a joke, depending on where you are in your career; you will definitely get less the younger and less experienced you are.
- Networking and knowing the right people is definitely the way to get ahead in Abbott. That's not to say that a meritocracy is not in place, because there definitely is, but there's still a lot of politicking that goes on and some people may not care for that.
- Organizationally, there are probably too many managers, directors and VPs, and that makes a lot of the lower folks resentful at time. However, those guys are all still wonderful and I personally believe that they work harder than most of the lower folks in the organization
- Abbott is slow to change, but that's just the nature of the industry

review_title: Scientist view of Abbott Diagnostics Division
pros: I enjoy working for Abbott Labs.  There is plenty of room for advancement.  Benefits are good and they are very friendly towards working mothers.
cons: There has been a lot of lay-offs in the last few years in my division (ADD) and an attempt at a sell-off and now at Lake County, IL there is downsizing that threatens my position.

review_title: Experienced and Career MInded People Pass On This Company - Major Downsizing in progress
pros: Finally starting to look at lean principles and utilize metrics as a means to understand and implement programs. Hiring inexperienced people without skills or the ability to communicate into upper level positions provides safe haven for non-performers.
cons: No advancement or promotions. Low wages and small yearly bonus. Company does not practice theprinciples it promotes. Does not demote or eliminate poor managers and staff members. Dangles carrotts but never delivers.

review_title: Great benefits, excellent salary, wonderful co-workers.
pros: Lots of opportunity to learn and grow; Employee safety and compliance with policy and procedure is a priority;
cons: Not all managers at this company are good leaders, and a persons success in many instances depends on the leadership of their manager.  Timelines are not always realistic but this is not always communicated upwards.

pros: There are good people here that are trying really hard, benefits, pension, 401K, annual bonus all good.
cons: Not much respect, Lousy mid level management, poor communication, no marketing visibility, not allowed to attend trade shows. Not allowed to observe clinical's, poor physical work environment.....

review_title: Excessive tiered management; lousy IT department and infrasturcture
pros: They will tallow you to facilitate a work life balance. Good. benefits.
cons:
Poor intranet and very fragmented access to benefits online. While it is great to have a 401k, FSA and other benefits the ability to reliably access them is equally important. This ability is nil. The ALEC credit union is a perfect example. Horrendous accessibility.

There also seems to be a very laxed attitude regarding FDA compliance. As long as ‘nobody gets hurt’ non-compliance issues are swept under the rug.

review_title: R&D company dealing with Eye Health Care. Specifically dealing with Lasik and OCT(Optical Coherence Tomography)
pros: Friendly profession atmosphere. Excellent benefits and vacation package. Emphasize work/life balance. Flex time.
cons: Flex time can be a disadvantage when needing help or direction on a project.

pros: Work life balance is attainable if you have a supportive manager who understands the business and likes people.  The benefits are great, particularly if you have children.
cons: Sr. Leadership has no concept of what goes on and is rude to employees with no fear of repercussion, employees are intimidated and resort to following orders rather than contribute ideas, no real cross training, poor communication among the ranks, face time is a MUST!

pros: Delivers consistently against shareholder expectations. Diverse portfolio of business. International growth provides opportunities for employees to expand their career potential.
cons: The organization typically manages from the top down and neglects to take into account the realities of the business. This often leads to decisions that later have to be undone or adversely impact the business in the short term.

pros: Opportunities to move up in organization, backed by Fortune 500 company
cons: Inconsistant Management, 5 Presidents in last 6 years.  Unfortunately tenure and past achievements are not viewed as an asset.  Yearly reduction in force in commonplace and moral has eroded to a dangerous low.

pros: Big company benefits. Medical etc.
cons: Abbott hasn't changed since 2010. The negative comments about management are the same. So, I'm thinking this is the culture. If you work for a competitor, look at the trend of Abbott hiring then giving an impossible to achieve, ensure failure dismissal plan. I personally had my boss give a sketchy review of annual plan, then bailing on me going vacation. Then was blamed for the plan not being complete in a few days

pros: The company offers a decent benefits package with good bonuses. Lots of travel if you have the right job. Great brands and interesting categories to operate in.
cons: If you don't like travel, some rolls have high expectation of travel. Slightly old fashioned in it's approach both from a marketing point of view and leadership style. i.e. the more senior you are, the more right you are.

pros: Receiving a salary for what you do.
cons: Lack of transparency of important decisions that affect employees and work. Negligence by giving high level tasks to only certain people because of friendship and power control.  Meetings and lunch with only preferred people to discuss work and decisions that affect the entire team.

review_title: A miserable and regressive workplace culture will destroy your soul
job_title: Senior Counsel in Abbott Park, IL
pros: Generous pension package (if you stay long enough), immense turnover opens lots of internal opportunities, company makes products that (generally) help people
cons: Restrictive and stifling environment, Legal Dep't devoid of meaningful work, cultureless, never-ending cycle of meetings, immense amount of administrative work, openly dismissive of innovation or new ideas, constant backstabbing (esp. thanks to lifers desperate to advance), terrible managers in Legal, incompetent admin staff

review_title: Don't judge a book by its cover.
job_title: Quality Professional in Abbott Park, IL
pros:
Benefits and recognition of company name on resume.
Generous vacation time.
Abbott has the potential to provide an interesting career filled with a variety of positions and develop a wide range of skill sets making it possible to experience a fullfilling career
cons:
Employees are not sufficiently valued and there is very limited opportunities for professional growth. 
Too much office politics and unprofessional conduct from employees is tolerated by management.
Low work morale due to constant layoff announcements by management.

review_title: Hmm it is what it is but a pretty good paying job.
pros: Company perks include free meals,  and the yearly company parties. They give out pretty good raffle prices at these parties too
cons: It is like the blind leading the blind.  Too much gossip on the floor, managers doing bad stuff with their subordinates, and a lot of favoritism.

pros: Worked in research using novel therapies in cancer therapy division. Worked on cutting edge breakthroughs including photodynamic gene-therapy methods.  Strong mentoring. Very collegial enviornment.
cons: A bit too political.  Did not think they developed people for better positions. Year end reviews were poorly done.  Feedback seemed difficult to get at times.

pros: The company has great the benfeits awesome support network, and they way they treat the people is awsome from a humanstic perpective.
cons: 20 staff managers  turn overs in  3 years. The paradigm shifts are crazy;  company is great; this plant's  infrastruture is bad. they simply cannot seem to get it right at this plant.

review_title: I had a great working experience with Abbott
pros: I had great leadership in my region and was able to accomplish some  of my career goals. One of my high points was qualifying for President's Club and going to Grand Caymen Islands!
cons: There was a reduction in force and I was part of the reduction, but was offered another position within the company.

review_title: Careful...the transformation has wiped out most of the IT jobs.

review_title: Stop hiring contractors and get employees

pros:
A genuinely world class facility
Learned a lot about operational excellence
Great work colleagues
Not bad benefits although not as good as they used to be...

Working environment quite often frustrating due to not so world class communications
Dull and mentally exhausting work if you are an assembler
Very little recognition for employees exceeding expectations
Career opportunities below industry average
Lot of evidence for a corpo rat race among mid senior level

review_title: Good company, but still need to change mindset for branded generics drug maker

job_title: Territory Manager in Great Neck, NY
pros: Salary, company car, cell phone, laptop, and the fact that you mostly worked in the field and autonomously without being micromanaged. Was there for 14 years.
cons: Towards the end of my career there (the last 3 years) it became an extremely stressful environment, and they were just looking to shrink the sales force without even wanting to terminate and pay unemployment, or offer severance packages to the employees.

pros:
director of the department is nice. 
clean place

She  targeted specific people  and favored people based on how good friends they are with her.. zero bonding with her own team.. friendly with other team... Most of the people loathed her. I left for the same reason

pros: I liked working for the company for about two years.  The salary was great and the benifits better than most companies.

review_title: Abbott destroys any creativity you once had, but pays well in the meantime.
job_title: Senior R&D Engineer in Temecula, CA

Management is quick to point out shortcomings and rarely compliments positive accomplishments. Technical abilities do not matter, achievements do not matter, only "perception" matters. Middle and upper management are entirely inbred with very little outside experience.

review_title: Was a great place to work until Corporate got more involved
pros: The company has great benefits, great products, and strong commitment to quality. In addition, it can throw a tremendous amount of resources at any problem.
cons: To much emphasis on appearances and micro managing from Chicago leads to low morale and overwhelming feeling that management is distrustful of its employees in Columbus.

review_title: You can build a lifetime career at Abbott.
pros: A large amount of opportunity and support for career development.  Great for those who can take the initiative and manage their own careers - it is a big place.  It is very important to have the support of your boss.  Fortunately there are a lot of good bosses at Abbott.
cons: Like any large company, there is a lot of bureaucracy - things can take forever to accomplish.  Anyone who is not a self-starter could get lost in the crowd.

pros:
* Steady employment if you continually do more work for same pay
